questions.text: Which of the following is correct sequence of the structure passing through parotid gland from superficial to deep?
questions.solution:
• Structures in the Parotid Gland:
    • The parotid gland contains three main structures that traverse and branch within it.
  • Sequence from Superficial to Deep:
    • Facial Nerve: Most superficial; enters through the upper part of the posteromedial surface and branches into terminal branches within the gland.
    • Retromandibular Vein: Located in the intermediate zone; formed by the union of superficial temporal and maxillary veins, dividing into anterior and posterior divisions.
    • External Carotid Artery: Pierces the lower part of the posteromedial surface; occupies the deep zone and divides into superficial temporal and maxillary arteries.
  • Correct Sequence:
    • So, (Option A) is the correct sequence: Facial nerve, Retromandibular vein, External carotid artery.

Why Not Others?

  • B. Retromandibular Vein, External Carotid Artery, Facial Nerve: Incorrect; the facial nerve is more superficial.
  • C. Facial Nerve, External Carotid Artery, Retromandibular Vein: Incorrect; retromandibular vein is located between the facial nerve and external carotid artery.
  • D. External Carotid Artery, Retromandibular Vein, Facial Nerve: Incorrect; the external carotid artery is the deepest structure.

Key Takeaway:

The correct sequence of structures passing through the parotid gland from superficial to deep is Facial nerve, Retromandibular vein, External carotid artery, with the facial nerve being the most superficial and the external carotid artery being the deepest structure.

Tags: Neet 2022

Reference: Textbook of anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-3, 4th Edition, Page no. 113; Textbook of Gray's anatomy, 42nd Edition, Page no. 634

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with episodes of swelling in her extremities, face, and gastrointestinal tract. These episodes have been occurring intermittently for several years and are often precipitated by minor trauma or stress. Which complement deficiency is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The symptoms described-episodic swelling in various body parts-are characteristic of Hereditary Angioneurotic Edema, a condition linked to a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor (C1-INH). This deficiency impairs the regulation of the complement and contact systems, leading to unregulated activation and subsequent swelling.

Key Takeaway:

Hereditary Angioneurotic Edema is associated with a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor, which can cause recurrent angioedema due to unregulated activation of the complement and contact systems.

Tags: Neet 2020

Tag line: Hard, clinical

Reference: Shastri, A. (2023). Immunology: Chapter 13 on Complement System, pp. 163-167

questions.text: Diagnostic power of a screening test is deduced from:
questions.solution:
• Predictive Value:
    • Refers to the probability that individuals with a positive test result actually have the disease (Positive Predictive Value, PPV) or that individuals with a negative test result truly do not have the disease (Negative Predictive Value, NPV).
    • It is influenced by sensitivity (the test's ability to identify true positives), specificity (the ability to identify true negatives), and the prevalence of the disease in the population.
    • Higher disease prevalence generally leads to higher PPV, while a lower prevalence reduces PPV, even if the test is highly sensitive and specific.
  • Sensitivity:
    • The proportion of true positives identified by the test.
    • Important for detecting the disease but does not directly assess the test's predictive power regarding actual patient outcomes.
  • Specificity:
    • The proportion of true negatives identified by the test.
    • Like sensitivity, it contributes to the test's effectiveness but not directly to predictive value.
  • Population Attributable Risk:
    • This term quantifies the proportion of a disease in the population that can be attributed to a specific risk factor, but it does not assess the diagnostic power of a screening test.

Why Not Other Options:

  • (a) Specificity: While important for test accuracy, it does not alone determine the predictive value.
  • (b) Population Attributable Risk: Irrelevant to screening test evaluation.
  • (c) Sensitivity: Similar to specificity, it is vital for the test's ability to detect disease but not for calculating predictive value.

Key Takeaways:

The diagnostic power of a screening test is best evaluated through its predictive value, which integrates sensitivity, specificity, and disease prevalence. Understanding how these factors interact helps to determine the test's effectiveness in clinical settings, influencing patient outcomes and public health strategies.

Tags: Neet 2023

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K.park, 27th Edition, chapter-4, Page no.155-157

questions.text: Which of the following is newly approved therapy in Cystic Fibrosis?
questions.solution:
• Newly Approved Therapies for Cystic Fibrosis:
    • IVACAFTOR:
      • Enhances CFTR channel opening and ion transport, specifically addressing the G551D mutation.
    • Lumacaftor and Tezacaftor:
      • These are "corrector" molecules that help in proper protein folding and trafficking for patients with the F508del mutation.
  • Management Components:
    • Anti-inflammatory medications and bronchodilators.
    • Antibiotic therapy (oral or aerosolized) for Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections.
    • Recombinant DNase aerosols to reduce mucus viscosity.
    • Nebulized hypertonic saline to aid in mucociliary clearance.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A. IVACAFTOR: While it is a treatment for CF, it is not the only newly approved therapy.
  • B. LUMACAFTOR: Also a treatment but not solely classified as newly approved.
  • C. TAZACAFTOR: Similar to lumacaftor; it functions as a corrector but does not stand alone as a newly approved therapy.

Key Takeaways:

  • All three therapies (Ivacaftor, Lumacaftor, and Tezacaftor) are considered newly approved for cystic fibrosis management.
  • These treatments enhance CFTR function and significantly improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A 68 year old male presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty starting urination, weak urinary stream, and nocturia. He denies any pain during urination. What is the most likely term to describe his condition?
questions.solution:
URINARY SYMPTOMS DEFINITIONS

Storage Symptoms:

  • Frequency - the patient considers that they void too often during the day.
  • Nocturia - the individual wakes at night at least once to void.
  • Strangury - a sensation of constantly needing to void.

Typically, the patient describes having to stand/sit for long periods with the sensation that micturition is imminent.

  • Urgency - a sudden compelling desire to pass urine that is difficult to defer.
  • Urge incontinence - involuntary urinary leakage, often a large volume, immediately preceded by the sensation of urgency.
  • Nocturnal enuresis - involuntary loss of urine during sleep.

Voiding Symptoms:

  • Hesitancy - when an individual has difficulty initiating micturition, resulting in a delay in the onset of voiding.
  • Reduced urinary stream - usually reported compared with previous performance or in comparison with the performance of others.
  • Intermittency - when urine flow stops and starts, on one or more occasions.
  • Straining - the muscular effort used in order to initiate, maintain or improve the urinary stream.
  • Incomplete emptying - the sensation that, at the end of micturition, bladder fullness persists.
  • Post Micturition dribble - when involuntary loss of urine occurs immediately after the individual has finished passing urine.

Option A: Urgency: This term refers to a sudden and compelling need to urinate, which is not easily deferred. It is often seen in conditions causing bladder irritation, such as urinary tract infections.

Option B: Nocturia: This term describes the need to wake up one or more times at night to urinate. While the patient reports nocturia, it is not the primary concern in this scenario.

Option C: Hesitancy: This is the difficulty in starting or maintaining a steady urine stream, often associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or other causes of urinary obstruction. It best describes the patient's primary symptom.

Option D: Dysuria: This term indicates painful or difficult urination, often due to infection or inflammation. The patient does not report pain, ruling out dysuria.

Key Takeaway:

  • Hesitancy is typically caused by urinary tract obstruction, most commonly due to BPH in older men.
  • Urgency can indicate bladder irritation or overactivity.

Tags:

Topic: Urinary symptoms

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ: Inicet May 2021 | FMGE Jan 2023

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 81, Pages 1448

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with fluctuating diplopia and ptosis, worse at the end of the day and after prolonged reading. Examination reveals bilateral ptosis, more pronounced on the left, and variable limitation of ocular movements in all directions. Pupillary reactions are normal. Ice pack test applied over the left eyelid improves the ptosis temporarily. Which of the following is the most specific diagnostic test for confirming the diagnosis of ocular myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
• Single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG) is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing ocular myasthenia gravis (OMG). It detects subtle abnormalities in neuromuscular transmission between individual muscle fibers, making it superior for identifying myasthenia gravis, particularly in ocular cases.

Ocular Myasthenia Gravis:

  • Definition: Ocular myasthenia gravis (OMG) is a form of myasthenia gravis (MG) limited to the extraocular muscles, causing symptoms such as ptosis, diplopia, and variable ophthalmoplegia. Unlike generalized MG, it does not involve the skeletal muscles of the body.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the production of autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors (AChR) at the neuromuscular junction, leading to impaired transmission of signals from nerves to muscles.
    • Ocular muscles are more susceptible to this disruption, causing weakness that fluctuates throughout the day.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Ptosis: Typically asymmetric and worsens with fatigue.
    • Diplopia: Fluctuating and variable in presentation, often worsening at the end of the day.
    • No pupil involvement: Pupils are usually spared, distinguishing OMG from other causes of ophthalmoplegia such as cranial nerve palsies.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Ice pack test: Cooling the eyelid can improve ptosis temporarily, a positive sign of myasthenia gravis.
    • Single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG): The most sensitive diagnostic test, detecting abnormalities in neuromuscular transmission.
    • Anti-AChR antibodies: May be present in systemic MG but are less commonly found in isolated ocular myasthenia.
    • Tensilon test: Historically used, but less commonly relied on today due to side effects and variability in response.
  • Treatment:
    • Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., pyridostigmine) to improve neuromuscular transmission.
    • Corticosteroids and immunosuppressants may be used in refractory cases.
    • Thymectomy: Considered in some patients, as thymomas are associated with MG.

Why Not Others:

  • A: Electromyography (EMG) of the extraocular muscles can show neuromuscular transmission defects but is less sensitive than SFEMG for OMG.
  • B: Serum anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies are positive in 50-70% of generalized myasthenia gravis cases but only in about 50% or fewer of patients with OMG, making it less specific for this condition.
  • D: The Tensilon (edrophonium) test temporarily improves weakness in myasthenia gravis but is not as reliable as SFEMG and can yield false positives or negatives.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ocular myasthenia gravis is characterized by fluctuating ptosis and diplopia with preserved pupillary responses. SFEMG is the definitive diagnostic tool, while the ice pack test can provide temporary improvement in symptoms. Treatment includes acetylcholinesterase inhibitors and possibly immunosuppressants or thymectomy.

#Ocular Myasthenia Gravis #neet 2019

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 8th ed, Saunders Elsevier; 2015. pg. 527-530.

Beta Receptors Action:

Comparative effects of iv infusion of following agents:

Approach to Question:

Raised SBP: Either Alpha 1/Beta 1

Decreased DBP: Beta 2

Reflex Tachycardia: Due to Vasodilation by Beta 2.

Option C: Alpha 1 Antagonist & Beta 2 agonist both decreases DBP so it's out.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A full term neonate presents with abdominal distension and failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life. An abdominal Xray shows dilated loops of bowel with a ground glass appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Meconium Ileus

Pathophysiology:

  • Meconium ileus is primarily caused by thick, sticky meconium obstructing the ileum.
  • It is most often associated with cystic fibrosis.

Clinical Features:

  • Abdominal distension is a common symptom.
  • Failure to pass meconium within 48 hours of birth is a key sign.
  • Vomiting can occur, especially if the obstruction is distal.

Diagnosis:

  • Abdominal X-ray shows dilated bowel loops with a ground glass or soap bubble appearance due to inspissated meconium.
  • Contrast enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic, showing a microcolon and potentially dislodging the meconium.

Management:

  • Contrast enema is the initial treatment to relieve the obstruction.
  • Surgical intervention may be necessary if the enema fails or if complications arise.

Complications:

  • Volvulus is a surgical emergency.
  • Perforation can lead to peritonitis.

Option A: Hirschsprung disease presents with delayed meconium passage and a distended abdomen, but the X Ray findings described are more characteristic of meconium ileus.

Option B: Meconium ileus, Contrast enema is Correct. Meconium ileus is associated with cystic fibrosis and presents with a characteristic "ground glass" appearance on X Ray. A contrast enema can be both diagnostic and therapeutic by helping to dislodge the thickened meconium.

Option C: Intestinal atresia presents with bilious vomiting and double bubble sign on Xray, not with the ground glass appearance described here.

Option D: Meconium plug syndrome also presents with delayed passage of meconium, but the ground glass appearance is more specific for meconium ileus.

Key Takeaways:

  • Meconium ileus is commonly associated with cystic fibrosis and presents with a characteristic ground glass appearance on X Ray.
  • Contrast enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic for meconium ileus.

Tags:

TOPIC: Meconium Ileus

Difficulty Level: Must Know

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 18, page 268

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with intermittent dysphagia for solids, especially when eating large pieces of meat. He denies any weight loss or pain. A barium swallow reveals a thin, circumferential narrowing at the lower esophagus. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the best initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Schatzki's Ring

  • A thin, circumferential ring of tissue at the squamocolumnar junction (lower esophagus).
  • Often associated with intermittent dysphagia, especially for solids.
  • Etiology:
    • Possibly due to chronic acid exposure and reflux, leading to scarring and narrowing.
    • Can be congenital or acquired.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Barium Swallow: Shows a narrow ringlike structure in the distal esophagus.
  • Endoscopy: Confirms the presence of a ring, usually at the gastroesophageal junction.

Management:

  • Esophageal Dilation: Mainstay of treatment for symptomatic relief.
  • Dietary Modification: Chewing food thoroughly, avoiding large bites.
  • PPIs: May be used if associated with GERD symptoms to prevent recurrence.
  • A web is distinguished from a Schatzki's ring in that both the proximal and distal surfaces of the web are lined by squamous mucosa; in a Schatzki's ring, the proximal side is lined with squamous mucosa and the distal side by columnar mucosa, coinciding with its location at the squamocolumnar junction.

Explanation of Options:

  1. Esophageal cancer; esophagectomy: Incorrect. Cancer presents with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and mass on imaging, unlike Schatzki's ring.
  2. Schatzki's ring; esophageal dilation: Correct. Schatzki's ring presents with intermittent dysphagia and is treated with dilation to relieve symptoms.
  3. Peptic stricture; proton pump inhibitors (PPIs): Incorrect. Peptic strictures usually present with a history of GERD and are not typically circumferential.
  4. Achalasia; Heller myotomy: Incorrect. Achalasia presents with dysphagia for both solids and liquids and shows a birdbeak appearance on barium swallow.

Key Points:

  • Schatzki's ring causes intermittent dysphagia for solids and is best diagnosed with a barium swallow.
  • Treatment primarily involves esophageal dilation, which effectively relieves symptoms.

Tags:

Topic: Schatzki's Ring

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-66 , page no. 1147

questions.text: Ujjwala scheme is for prevention of:
questions.solution:
• Ujjwala Scheme is an initiative by the Ministry of Women and Child Development in India.
  • Objective: To prevent child trafficking and support victims of trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation.
  • Support Provided: Rescue, rehabilitation, reintegration, and repatriation of victims, with services including shelter, legal aid, counselling, and vocational training.

Key Components of the Ujjwala Scheme:

  • Target Group: Women and children who are victims of commercial sexual exploitation.
  • Prevention: Awareness and sensitization in high-risk trafficking areas.
  • Rescue: Assistance in rescuing victims from exploitation.
  • Rehabilitation: Temporary shelter, food, counseling, legal aid, and training for victims.
  • Reintegration: Reuniting victims with families or helping them integrate into society.
  • Repatriation: Support for victims trafficked across borders.
  • Funding: Centrally funded, with contributions from state governments and NGOs.
  • Implementation: Carried out by state governments, union territories, and NGOs in anti-trafficking.

Key Components of the Ujjwala Scheme:

Why Not Other Options:

  • (a) Child abuse:
    The Ujjwala Scheme does not specifically address child abuse; it is aimed at preventing and addressing child trafficking and aiding victims of commercial sexual exploitation.
  • (c) Child labour:
    Although child labour is a major social issue, the Ujjwala Scheme's scope is focused on trafficking prevention and does not directly target child labour prevention.
  • (d) Child marriage:
    Ujjwala is not designed to prevent child marriage. Separate schemes like the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act address this issue specifically.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ujjwala Scheme focuses on preventing and addressing child trafficking.
  • It provides comprehensive support for victims, including rescue, rehabilitation, and reintegration through collaborative efforts with states and NGOs.

Tags: Inicet may 2021

Reference: NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAMS OF INDIA, 12th Edition, J. Kishore, chapter-10, Page no. 312-316.

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient presents with foul smelling ear discharge. Discharge was scanty in nature, patient also experience vertigo intermittently. HRCT temporal bone was done which is suggestive of cholesteatoma in epitympanum and mesotympanum with erosion of incus. On endoscopy the tympanic membrane appeared as the picture given below. Most appropriate Next step in management is?
questions.solution:
The picture shown above is suggestive of attic retraction pocket with cholesteatoma flakes.

Cholesteatoma is presence of keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium in any part of temporal bone where it is usually not present. Eg middle ear, mastoid, petrous Apex.

In its basal layer cholesteatoma has got enzymes like collagenase and acid phosphatase which cause the bony erosion, helping the middle ear infection to reach the surrounding areas leading to various complications.

Patient present here with scant, painless and foul smelling discharge because of otitis and bone erosion by cholesteatoma and infection with anaerobic organism.

The main management of unsafe CSOM is mastoid exploration with removal of disease from the mastoid, followed by removal of disease from middle ear.

Option A: Discharge in unsafe otitis media is mainly because of bone erosion hence medical management with local and systemic antibiotics does not have much affect on drying of discharge.

Option C: Only Myringoplasty is not sufficient in eradicating the disease from middle ear and mastoid cavity.

Option D: Radical mastoidectomy is indicated in extensive cholesteatoma following unsafe CSOM with dead ear.

Unresectable cholesteatoma extending upto petrous Apex, promontory cochlear fistula.

Key Takeaway:

Unsafe CSOM Management - Modified Radical Mastoidectomy. No role of medical management

questions.text: What is the standard temperature and pressure used in an autoclave for effective sterilization?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Correct
    • Effective sterilization in an autoclave typically occurs at 121°C and 15 psi pressure.
  • Option B: Incorrect
    • 100°C at 10 psi is not sufficient for effective sterilization.
  • Option C: Incorrect
    • 150°C at 20 psi is higher than the standard requirements.
  • Option D: Incorrect
    • 130°C at 25 psi is also above the standard sterilization conditions.

AUTOCLAVE:

Definition:

An autoclave is a device used for sterilizing equipment and materials by exposing them to high-temperature steam under pressure. It is widely used in medical, laboratory, and industrial settings to ensure that items are free from microorganisms, including bacterial spores, which are highly resistant to heat.

Operation:

  • Temperature and Pressure:
    • The standard sterilization conditions are 121°C (250°F) and 15 psi (pounds per square inch) of pressure, maintained for 15 to 30 minutes, depending on the type and quantity of items being sterilized.
  • Mechanism:
    • Steam is generated inside the autoclave chamber and pressurized to reach the required temperature, penetrating items and killing microorganisms by denaturing their proteins.

Uses:

  • Medical Sterilization:
    • Sterilizing surgical instruments, glassware, and other medical tools.
  • Laboratory Sterilization:
    • Preparing culture media and sterilizing lab equipment.
  • Industrial Applications:
    • Sterilizing materials used in manufacturing processes.

Advantages:

  • Effective Sterilization:
    • Ensures thorough destruction of microorganisms, including resistant bacterial spores.
  • Reliability:
    • Provides consistent and repeatable results with proper operation and maintenance.

Key Points:

  • Autoclaving is a reliable and widely accepted method for achieving high levels of sterilization.
  • Proper training and maintenance are essential to ensure effective sterilization and safety.

KEY TAKE AWAY: The standard autoclave settings for effective sterilization are 121°C at 15 psi pressure.

Tags: Must know | fmge | neet 2022

Tags: Clinical Question, Moderate

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2020). Sterilization and Disinfection. Retrieved from CDC - Sterilization and Disinfection

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient receiving cancer chemotherapy was brought to the medicine department with complaints of anorexia, abdominal distension with flank pain, oliguria, fatigue and muscle cramps. He was later diagnosed with tumor lysis syndrome. Which of the following is the fastest uric acid lowering therapy in tumor lysis syndrome to prevent renal damage?
questions.solution:
Rasburicase is a recombinant uricase that has been shown to lower urate levels more effectively than allopurinol.

Indications:

  • Management of elevated plasma uric acid levels in pediatric and adult patients with leukemia & lymphoma
  • Solid tumor malignancies who are receiving anticancer therapy expected to result in tumor lysis and significant hyperuricemia.

Side effects:

  • Hemolysis in G6PD-deficient patients,
  • Methemoglobinemia
  • Acute renal failure
  • Anaphylaxis

Other includes vomiting, fever, nausea, headache, abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea, and mucositis.

Option A: Allopurinol (hypoxanthine analog) decreases the production of uric acid by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase. These are indicated as drug of choice for chronic gout in the inter-critical period (between two acute attacks).

Option B: Febuxostat (a non-purine drug) decreases the production of uric acid by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase. These are indicated as drug of choice for chronic gout in the inter-critical period (between two acute attacks).

Option D: Furosemide causes hyperuricemia and should be avoided in patients with gout.

Key Takeaway:

  • Rasburicase is administered by I.V. route and are indicated only in patients with chronic gout refractory to other treatments & to prevent hyperuricemia during tumor lysis syndrome.

Tags:

  • Rasburicase
  • May know
  • Fmge June 2022 l Neet 2022

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 850

questions.text: A subcentre in a hilly area caters to a population of:
questions.solution:
In hilly, tribal, or difficult areas, a subcentre typically caters to a population of around 3,000. Therefore, the correct answer is:

(c) 3000.

Explanation:

  • In hilly, tribal, or difficult areas, subcentres cater to a population of around 3,000. This is in contrast to plain areas, where the subcentre usually serves 5,000 people.
  • Health infrastructure in such regions is adjusted to accommodate the challenges of terrain and accessibility, leading to a smaller population per subcentre.
  • Population norms for health centers in India:

Additional Points:

  • Health Assistant norms:
    • Plain area: 1 per 30,000 population
    • Tribal/hilly areas: 1 per 20,000 population
  • Health Worker/Multi-purpose Worker norms:
    • Plain area: 1 per 5,000 population
    • Tribal/hilly areas: 1 per 3,000 population
  • Anganwadi Worker norms:
    • Plain area: 1 per 400-800 population
    • Tribal/hilly areas: 1 per 300-800 population

Key Takeaways:

  • Subcentres in hilly and tribal areas are designed for 3,000 people due to geographical difficulties.
  • Population norms vary based on terrain, ensuring better healthcare access in harder-to-reach regions.

Tags: Neet 2022

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-23, Page no. 1001-1005.

questions.text: A 40 years old male presents with recurrent oral, genital ulcers. He has usually 4-5 episodes of painful oral/genital ulcers per year for last 2 years. Now he presents with painful acute red eyes for last 2 days and was diagnosed to have uveitis. Mild leucocytosis and thrombocytosis is present. Antinuclear antibody, ANA-profile is negative and pathergy test is positive. what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Behcet disease:

  • Behcet syndrome is a systemic vasculitis and presents with skin and mucosal lesions, uveitis, arthritis, major arterial and venous vessel disease, and gastrointestinal and neurologic manifestations.
  • It is relatively rare before the late teens and after age 50. Males and females are equally affected; however, males frequently have more severe disease and poorer outcomes.
  • Diagnosis: Behcet syndrome is diagnosed clinically. The most commonly used and best performing diagnostic criteria are the International Study Group (ISG) criteria (sensitivity ~95%, specificity ~96%); patients need to have recurrent oral ulcers plus two of the following four clinical manifestations: recurrent genital ulcers, skin lesions, eye lesions, or a positive pathergy test.
  • Vascular Manifestation can be seen in up-to 40% of the cases - superficial and deep venous thrombosis, inferior vena cava syndrome, pulmonary artery involvement, intracardiac thrombi and cerebral venous sinus thrombosis.
  • Laboratory Manifestation: Up to 50-60% of patients, depending on where they are from, can be positive for HLA B*51; however, it is not used as a diagnostic test because it is also found in up to 20% of the normal population.
  • Therapy
  • Oral topical glucocorticoid, oral colchicine, for oral ulcers
  • Apremilast-Phosphodiesterase 4 Inhibitor.
  • Uveitis-Glucocorticoids, Azathioprine, Infliximab
  • Gastrointestinal Involvement-Azathioprine, Infliximab

Causes of positive Pathergy Test:

  • Behcet disease
  • Pyoderma Gangrenosum
  • Sweet syndrome
  • Crohn's disease

Topic: Vasculitis Syndromes

Difficulty level: Must Know

Reference: Harrison principle of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, page no 2817

questions.text: A 16 year old female with severe persistent asthma is placed on multiple medications. She has been taking her medications as instructed, but one of the Medicine is causing her to have tachycardia, nausea, and jitteriness. She has been informed of the need to measure serum levels of this medication.Which medication is responsible for the above given undesirable side effects?
questions.solution:
• The methylxanthine agent is given in asthma because of its prominent bronchodilatory effect.
  • These agents have a low therapeutic index and often can cause adverse effects.
  • Narrow therapeutic index drug has low safety of margin. Hence, it requires monitoring of blood levels -Therapeutic drug monitoring.
    • Normal therapeutic range: 5-15 mg/dl
    • It is degraded by CYP1A2.

Side effects:

Mnemonic [DSP having Nausea]

  • Diuresis
  • Seizures.
  • Palpitation and arrhythmias
  • Nausea/vomiting/diarrhea
  • Pulsatile headache.

Option A: Ipratropium bromide is a short acting inhaled anticholinergic bronchodilator, Administered as aerosol, they produce minimal antimuscarinic side effects due to poor systemic absorption.

Option B: Montelukast and zafirlukast are very safe drugs; produce few side effects like abdominal pain, headache and rashes

Option C: Zileuton(Lipoxygenase inhibitor) inhibits synthesis of LTB4 (chemotactic) and LTC4 and LTD4 (bronchoconstrictor). Limiting features of this drug are short duration of action and hepatotoxicity.

Key Takeaway

  • Methylxanthines directly stimulate the heart and increase force of myocardial contractions. They tend to increase heart rate

questions.text: A 28 year old man is brought to the emergency room after being found unconscious. He opens his eyes to pain, makes incomprehensible sounds, and withdraws from pain. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.solution:
Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS):

  • Eye Opening (E):
    • E4: Spontaneous
    • E3: To speech
    • E2: To pain
    • E1: None
  • Verbal Response (V):
    • V5: Oriented
    • V4: Confused
    • V3: Inappropriate words
    • V2: Incomprehensible sounds
    • V1: None
  • Motor Response (M):
    • M6: Obeys commands
    • M5: Localizes pain
    • M4: Withdraws from pain
    • M3: Flexion (decorticate posture)
    • M2: Extension (decerebrate posture)
    • M1: None

Option A: 8: The GCS score is calculated as follows: Eye Opening (E2), Verbal Response (V2), and Motor Response (M4).

Option B: Score 9 This would require a higher verbal or motor response.

Option C: Score 10 A GCS of 10 suggests better responsiveness.

Option D: Score 11 Requires an even higher level of response.

Key Takeaways:

  • GCS 8 indicates severe brain injury, often requiring immediate medical intervention.
  • GCS is essential for assessing consciousness and determining the need for further neurological evaluation.

Tags:

Topic: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

Difficulty Level: Must Know

choices.text: Arrange immediate transfer to a PCI-capable facility for primary PCI
Start medical management with antiplatelet and anticoagulant agents only
Administer nitrates and morphine, and observe for symptom resolution

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with chest pain that started two hours ago. Her ECG shows 2 mm ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V4. She has no contraindications to medications. The nearest PCI-capable facility is three hours away. According to AHA guidelines, which of the following is the best next step?
questions.solution:
Clinical Presentation Analysis:

  • Symptoms:
    • Chest pain started two hours ago
  • ECG Findings:
    • ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V4
      • Indicates anterior wall myocardial infarction
  • Logistical Considerations:
    • PCI-capable facility is three hours away

AHA Guidelines for Reperfusion Therapy:

  • Time from Symptom Onset:
    • Reperfusion therapy is most beneficial when performed early.
  • Preferred Reperfusion Strategy:
    • Primary PCI if it can be performed within 120 minutes of first medical contact.
  • When PCI is Delayed:
    • If anticipated delay to PCI is over 120 minutes, fibrinolytic therapy should be administered within 30 minutes of hospital arrival.

Evaluation of Options:

  • Option A: Arrange immediate transfer to a PCI-capable facility
    • Incorrect, as transfer would cause a significant delay (>120 minutes).
  • Option B: Administer fibrinolytic therapy immediately
    • Correct, aligns with AHA guidelines when PCI is not feasible within 120 minutes.
  • Option C: Start medical management with antiplatelet and anticoagulant agents only
    • Incorrect, reperfusion therapy is necessary.
  • Option D: Administer nitrates and morphine, and observe
    • Incorrect, delays reperfusion and increases myocardial damage.
  • Option E: Schedule PCI for the next day
    • Incorrect, delays reperfusion beyond recommended time frames.

Contraindications to Fibrinolytic Therapy:

  • Absolute Contraindications:
    • Active internal bleeding
    • History of hemorrhagic stroke
    • Recent intracranial or intraspinal surgery
    • Severe uncontrolled hypertension
  • Relative Contraindications:
    • Pregnancy
    • Recent trauma
    • Peptic ulcer disease

Conclusion:

  • The patient requires urgent reperfusion.
  • Fibrinolytic therapy is indicated as PCI cannot be performed within 120 minutes.
  • The patient has no contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Administer fibrinolytic therapy when PCI is not available within 120 minutes of first medical contact.
  • Fibrinolytics should be given within 30 minutes of hospital arrival.
  • Time to reperfusion is critical; choose the fastest effective method available.

Tags:

Topic: Cardiology, STEMI, Fibrinolytic Therapy,

Difficulty: Must Know

questions.text: Which non-fermenting gram-negative bacilli are particularly known for causing respiratory infections in hospitalized patients?
questions.solution:
• Acinetobacter baumannii:
    • Known for causing nosocomial respiratory infections, particularly in ICU settings.
    • It is often associated with ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), bloodstream infections, and wound infections in hospitalized patients.
    • Multidrug resistance is a significant concern, with increasing resistance to carbapenems and other antibiotics.

Why not other options:

  • A. Burkholderia pseudomallei:
    • Can cause respiratory infections but is primarily associated with melioidosis and is more prevalent in tropical regions. It is community-acquired rather than a common hospital-acquired infection.
  • C. Lactobacillus spp.:
    • A non-pathogenic, fermentative bacterium involved in probiotic functions in the gut. It is not linked to hospital-associated respiratory infections.
  • D. Streptococcus pneumoniae:
    • A gram-positive coccus, commonly causing community-acquired pneumonia, but does not belong to the group of non-fermenting gram-negative bacilli.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Acinetobacter baumannii is a major nosocomial pathogen, particularly linked to ICU-related respiratory infections such as VAP.
  2. It is part of a broader group of non-fermenting gram-negative bacilli, along with Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, which are also significant in hospital-acquired infections.
  3. Its multidrug resistance presents challenges in treatment, leading to higher morbidity and mortality in hospitalized patients.

Tags: Neet 2020

Tag Line: EASY

Reference: Shastri, A. (2021). Essentials of Medical Microbiology (3rd ed.). Publisher, Chapter-65, pp-642.

questions.text: Which fungus is primarily responsible for causing Tinea Nigra?
questions.solution:
• Malassezia furfur: Associated with conditions like dandruff and tinea versicolor, but not responsible for Tinea Nigra.
  • Pityrosporum ovale: A synonym for Malassezia furfur, also not involved in Tinea Nigra.
  • Hortaea werneckii: The correct pathogen responsible for Tinea Nigra, characterized by dark, painless skin lesions on the palms or soles.
  • Candida albicans: A yeast commonly linked to candidiasis, not involved in Tinea Nigra.

Why Not Others:

  • a) Malassezia furfur: Involved in other skin conditions, not Tinea Nigra.
  • b) Pityrosporum ovale: Synonym for Malassezia furfur, hence irrelevant to Tinea Nigra.
  • d) Candida albicans: Related to different fungal infections, specifically candidiasis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Tinea Nigra is caused by Hortaea werneckii.
  • Identifying the causative agent is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment.

Tags: Inicet may 2023

Tag Line: Easy

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of intermittent episodes of ocular pain and blurred vision presents with an acute attack of angle-closure glaucoma. Her intraocular pressure (IOP) is 48 mmHg, and gonioscopy reveals a closed angle in both eyes. Initial medical management with systemic and topical medications lowers the IOP. What is the most definitive surgical intervention to prevent recurrence of angle closure?
questions.solution:
• A. Trabeculectomy: This is a surgical procedure to create an alternative drainage pathway for aqueous humor, lowering IOP in chronic glaucoma cases. It is not the first-line definitive procedure for acute angle-closure glaucoma, as it does not directly address the cause of the angle closure (pupil block).
  • B. Peripheral iridotomy: This is the gold standard definitive treatment for primary angle-closure glaucoma. It creates a small hole in the peripheral iris using a laser (usually YAG laser), allowing the aqueous humor to bypass the pupil block and flow from the posterior to the anterior chamber, preventing future episodes of angle closure.
  • C. Cyclophotocoagulation: This laser treatment reduces aqueous humor production by partially destroying the ciliary body. It is typically used for refractory glaucoma cases and is not the first-line intervention for angle-closure glaucoma.
  • D. Ahmed glaucoma valve implantation: This surgical procedure involves implanting a drainage device to control IOP in refractory or severe glaucoma cases. It is used for advanced or secondary glaucoma but is not the definitive treatment for angle closure.

Surgical Management of Primary Angle-Closure Glaucoma (PACG):

  1. Laser Peripheral Iridotomy (LPI):
    • First-line definitive treatment for acute and chronic PACG.
    • A laser creates a small hole in the peripheral iris, bypassing the pupil block, equalizing pressure between the posterior and anterior chambers, and reopening the angle.
    • Indicated in both the affected and fellow eye, as the unaffected eye is at high risk for developing angle closure.
  2. Laser Peripheral Iridoplasty:
    • In cases where laser iridotomy does not fully open the angle, laser iridoplasty can shrink the peripheral iris, pulling it away from the trabecular meshwork.
  3. Trabeculectomy:
    • Indicated if IOP remains uncontrolled despite iridotomy or if there is significant optic nerve damage.
    • Creates an alternative drainage pathway, lowering IOP long-term.
  4. Lens Extraction:
    • In eyes with a thickened lens, early cataract surgery (clear lens extraction) can deepen the anterior chamber and reduce the risk of angle closure.
    • Considered in patients with coexisting cataracts or in cases where laser iridotomy is insufficient.
  5. Cyclodestructive Procedures:
    • Reserved for refractory cases where IOP remains uncontrolled despite other interventions.
    • Cyclophotocoagulation targets the ciliary body to reduce aqueous production.
  6. Glaucoma Drainage Devices:
    • Devices such as the Ahmed valve may be used in patients with secondary glaucoma or advanced, refractory cases, but they are not first-line for PACG.

Why not other options:

  • Trabeculectomy (A): This procedure is for chronic glaucoma, not angle-closure, as it doesn't resolve the cause of the angle closure (pupil block).
  • Cyclophotocoagulation (C): Reduces aqueous humor production but is reserved for refractory glaucoma cases, not angle closure.
  • Ahmed glaucoma valve implantation (D): A drainage device used for severe or refractory glaucoma but is not the first-line treatment for angle-closure glaucoma.

Key Takeaways:

  • Laser peripheral iridotomy is the definitive treatment for PACG, preventing further episodes of angle closure.
  • Trabeculectomy and lens extraction may be considered for chronic or refractory cases where IOP control remains inadequate after laser intervention.

#Surgical Management of Primary Angle-Closure Glaucoma #neet pg 2019

Reference: Kanski J.J., Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 8th Edition, Page 376.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Lights criteria?
questions.solution:
• Light's Criteria are used to distinguish exudative from transudative pleural effusions. The criteria include:
    1. Pleural fluid/serum protein > 0.5
    2. Pleural fluid/serum LDH > 0.6
    3. Pleural fluid LDH > 2/3 of the normal upper serum limit
  • Triglyceride levels are not part of Light's criteria; they are more relevant in diagnosing chylothorax.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A. Pleural fluid LDH > 2/3 Upper normal serum limit: This is part of Light's criteria.
  • C. Pleural fluid/serum LDH > 0.6: Correctly included in Light's criteria.
  • D. Pleural fluid/serum protein > 0.5: Also part of Light's criteria.

Key Takeaways:

  • Light's Criteria help in identifying exudative effusion.
  • Triglycerides are used to assess chylothorax, not pleural effusion classification.

Topic: Pleural disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in COPD and its presence should initiate evaluation for other causes of Lung disease?
questions.solution:
• Clubbing:
    • Not a typical finding in COPD; indicates potential underlying lung pathology.
    • Often associated with conditions like lung cancer or interstitial lung disease.
  • Common Symptoms of COPD:
    • Cough: Persistent cough often productive of sputum.
    • Sputum production: Chronic sputum production is a hallmark.
    • Exertional dyspnea: Difficulty breathing during physical activities.
  • Physical Findings in COPD:
    • Cyanosis:
      • Common in chronic bronchitis, indicating chronic hypoxia.
      • Patients often referred to as "blue bloaters".
    • Hoover sign:
      • Characterized by paradoxical inward movement of the rib cage during inspiration.
      • Reflects diaphragmatic dysfunction due to hyperinflation.
    • Reduced diaphragmatic movement:
      • Results from poor diaphragmatic execution during respiration.
      • Sign of advanced disease where accessory muscles compensate.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A) Cyanosis:
    • Indicative of hypoxemia, commonly seen in chronic bronchitis patients.
  • C) Hoover sign:
    • A significant clinical finding in advanced COPD, pointing to changes in diaphragmatic mechanics.
  • D) Reduced diaphragmatic movement during respiration:
    • A typical feature in COPD due to hyperinflation affecting respiratory mechanics.

Key Takeaways:

  • Clubbing is not associated with COPD; its presence necessitates investigation for other lung diseases.
  • Common COPD symptoms include cough, sputum production, and dyspnea, while clubbing suggests a more serious underlying condition.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic for a vision assessment before applying for a pilot license. He reports difficulty distinguishing between certain colors, particularly reds and greens, but has normal visual acuity. Family history reveals that his maternal uncle also had similar difficulties. Based on this information, which of the following types of color vision deficiency is he most likely experiencing?
questions.solution:
• Protanopia:
    • Protanopia is characterized by the absence of red cones (L-cones), leading to difficulty distinguishing red from green.
    • The X-linked recessive inheritance pattern explains the family history, as males are more commonly affected, and maternal male relatives may also exhibit similar issues.
    • Common symptoms include normal visual acuity with specific red-green discrimination difficulty, aligning with the patient's presentation.
  • Differentiating from Other Options:
    • Tritanopia affects blue-yellow discrimination and is rarer, with no difficulty in red-green distinction.
    • Deuteranopia is also a red-green deficiency due to the absence of green cones (M-cones), but given the specific report of trouble with reds, protanopia is more likely.
    • Achromatopsia is a complete absence of color vision, generally accompanied by other visual issues like photophobia and nystagmus, which this patient lacks.

Why Not Other Options?

  • A) Tritanopia: Causes blue-yellow confusion, not red-green.
  • B) Deuteranopia: Involves green cone deficiency and can also cause red-green confusion, but the specific difficulty with red suggests protanopia.
  • D) Achromatopsia: Leads to total color blindness and additional symptoms, which are not seen here.

Key Takeaways:

  • Color blindness primarily affects color perception due to cone photopigment deficiencies.
  • Protanopia (red cone absence) and deuteranopia (green cone absence) are the most common forms of red-green color blindness and follow X-linked recessive inheritance, impacting males more frequently.
  • Color vision testing (like Ishihara plates) helps confirm the type and severity of color vision deficiency.

#color blindness

Reference: Parson's diseases of the eye, 22nd edition, section VI, chapter 28, pg.109.

questions.text: Maternal Mortality Rate is calculated by:
questions.solution:
• Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births within a specific time period.
  • Definition: It captures deaths due to complications from pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days post-delivery.
  • Purpose of MMR: Assesses healthcare quality, as higher rates can indicate deficiencies in maternal care and access to skilled healthcare providers.
  • Focus on Pregnancy-Related Deaths: MMR targets deaths directly related to pregnancy and delivery, distinguishing it from general mortality statistics.
  • Used by WHO: Standardized by the World Health Organization (WHO) for tracking global maternal health trends and comparing healthcare quality across regions.

Why Not Other Options:

  • (a) Maternal deaths/live birth:
    • Does not meet global standards for MMR calculation; lacks specificity and broad applicability.
  • (b) Maternal deaths/1000 live births:
    • Would overestimate MMR, as maternal deaths are comparatively rare and thus better captured per 100,000 live births.
  • (d) Maternal deaths/100000 population:
    • This includes the general population, which dilutes focus on reproductive risks and healthcare outcomes for mothers specifically.

Key Takeaways:

  • Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) is expressed as maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, capturing deaths due to pregnancy or childbirth complications.
  • Indicator of Maternal Health Services: A crucial public health indicator used to measure healthcare system effectiveness and maternal care quality.
  • Focus on Risk Reduction: Effective MMR reduction strategies focus on access to prenatal care, skilled birth attendants, and emergency obstetric care.

Tags: Inicet may 2023

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-09, Page no. 622-626.

questions.text: A patient with a known pituitary adenoma develops sudden onset of bilateral ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and severe headache. What complication should be suspected?
questions.solution:
• A. Pituitary apoplexy: Characterized by sudden headache, visual disturbances, and cranial nerve palsies, often requiring emergency intervention.
  • B. Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Can cause ophthalmoplegia but typically presents with more systemic symptoms like fever and sepsis.
  • C. Acute sinusitis: Does not usually cause ophthalmoplegia or severe sudden headache.
  • D. Temporal arteritis: Typically presents with headache, jaw claudication, and vision loss without ophthalmoplegia.

Key Takeaways: Pituitary apoplexy is a medical emergency often presenting with severe headache, vision loss, and cranial nerve involvement.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a painless swelling in the inferior pole of the parotid gland. The swelling has been slowly increasing in size over the past 6 months. The patient has a 40-year history of smoking but denies any pain or facial weakness. On examination, there is a well-defined, firm mass in the inferior pole of the parotid gland without overlying skin changes or tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Warthin's Tumour (Adenolymphoma)

  • Benign tumour of the parotid gland with oncocytic epithelial cells in lymphoid stroma.
  • Epidemiology: Predominantly affects men >60 years, strongly linked to smoking.
  • Location: Mostly in the parotid gland (inferior pole), rarely involves periparotid nodes.
  • Clinical Features: Painless, slow-growing swelling; facial nerve involvement is rare. May present bilaterally.
  • Malignant Transformation: Extremely rare.
  • Histopathology: Cystic and solid areas with lymphoid stroma and papillary projections.
  • Treatment: Complete surgical excision. Recurrence is rare.

Option A) Pleomorphic adenoma: Although a common benign tumour of the parotid gland, pleomorphic adenoma is not typically associated with smoking and usually presents in younger patients. It also lacks the typical cystic features of Warthin's tumour.

Option B) Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: This malignant salivary gland tumour may present with facial nerve involvement, pain, or rapid growth, which are not seen in this patient.

Option C) Warthin's tumor: Correct. Warthin's tumor is strongly associated with smoking, occurs in the parotid gland, and presents as a painless, slow-growing mass, often seen in older men. It has cystic components and rarely causes facial palsy.

Option D) Acinic cell carcinoma: This is a slow-growing malignant tumor, but it is less common and may involve facial nerve palsy, which is not seen in this case.

Key Points:

Strong association with smoking. Presents as a painless, slowly enlarging mass in older men.

TAGS:

  • Difficulty Level: Good to Know
  • Topic: Warthin's Tumour
  • PYQ: NEET PG 2022

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 54, Pages -840

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents with fatigue, right upper quadrant discomfort, and intermittent jaundice. She has a history of hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine. Laboratory investigations show:
ALT: 120 IU/L, AST: 110 IU/L
Alkaline phosphatase: Normal
Bilirubin: Normal
Elevated total protein with hypergammaglobulinemia
Autoimmune serologies reveal:
Positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) and smooth muscle antibody (SMA)
Elevated IgG levels
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. Key Clinical Features of AIH:
    • Hepatocellular injury: Elevated ALT and AST levels with normal alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin indicate a hepatocellular pattern of injury.
    • Autoimmune markers: Positive ANA and SMA, along with elevated IgG levels, strongly suggest AIH.
    • Hypergammaglobulinemia: A hallmark of AIH, reflecting the autoimmune nature of the disease.
  2. Exclusion of Other Options:
    • PBC (A): Typically presents with elevated alkaline phosphatase and positive antimitochondrial antibody (AMA). Not observed here.
    • PSC (C): Associated with biliary strictures seen on cholangiography and elevated ALP. Commonly coexists with inflammatory bowel disease.
    • NASH (D): Generally associated with metabolic syndrome, obesity, and ALT > AST, none of which are present.
  3. Diagnosis Confirmation:
    • The diagnosis of AIH can be confirmed with a liver biopsy, which typically shows interface hepatitis (lymphocytic infiltration at the portal-parenchymal interface).

Management:

  • Induction Therapy: Prednisone alone or in combination with azathioprine.
  • Maintenance Therapy: Azathioprine for long-term control.

Key Takeaways:

  • Autoimmune hepatitis is a common cause of hepatocellular liver injury in young to middle-aged women, often associated with other autoimmune diseases.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent progression to cirrhosis.

Tags:

  • Topic: Autoimmune Liver Disease, Hepatocellular Injury,
  • Difficulty: Must Know

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 2609, 12, 25

choices.text: It is characterized by the presence of Homer Wright rosettes
It shows extensive necrosis with dystrophic calcification
It is associated with the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes
It exhibits spindle-shaped tumor cells arranged in a storiform pattern

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric ophthalmology clinic with a white pupil in his right eye noticed by his mother during a flash photograph. A clinical examination confirms the presence of a mass in the right eye, and further imaging reveals a mass consistent with retinoblastoma. An enucleation is performed, and histopathological examination of the specimen shows nests of malignant cells with scant cytoplasm, round to oval nuclei, and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. Which of the following statements best describes the histopathological findings seen in this case?
questions.solution:
• Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a hallmark of retinoblastoma, indicating differentiation towards photoreceptor cells. They consist of tumor cells arranged around a central lumen, reflecting retinal cell differentiation.
  • Other Histopathological Features:
    • Nests of Malignant Cells with scant cytoplasm and high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio.
    • Calcification may be seen, though not a defining feature.
  • Histopathological Features:
    • Nests of Malignant Cells: Composed of poorly differentiated neuroectodermal cells.
    • Flexner-Wintersteiner Rosettes: Classic histopathological finding, indicative of differentiation towards photoreceptor cells.

Additional Points on Retinoblastoma:

  • Pathology: Tumor originates from immature retinal cells (retinoblasts).
  • Other Histological Findings: Small round blue cells, high mitotic index, areas of necrosis.
  • Spread: Can invade the optic nerve, choroid, and sclera, and metastasize.
  • Management: Includes enucleation, chemotherapy, and focal therapies (cryotherapy, laser).

Why Not Other Options:

  • A) Homer Wright rosettes: Associated with neuroblastoma, not retinoblastoma; feature central fibrillary material.
  • B) Extensive necrosis with dystrophic calcification: Necrosis may occur, but rosettes are a classic feature in retinoblastoma histology.
  • D) Spindle-shaped tumor cells in a storiform pattern: This pattern is typical of sarcomas or fibrous tumors, not retinoblastoma.

Key Takeaways: Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children, with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes as a key histopathological feature, and is often linked to mutations in the RB1 gene.

Reference: Parson's diseases of the eye, 22nd edition, section VI, chapter.28 p.378-382

choices.text: Wide surgical debridement with broad spectrum antibiotics
Local wound care and pain management

questions.text: A 55 year old diabetic male presents with severe pain, redness, and swelling in his right leg. Examination reveals crepitus and foul smelling discharge from the wound. A "finger test" reveals easy dissection of tissue with minimal resistance. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Synergistic Spreading Gangrene (Necrotising Fasciitis)

  • A severe bacterial infection that affects the deep fascia and leads to widespread tissue necrosis if untreated.
  • Also known as necrotizing fasciitis, it can occur in the abdominal wall (Meleney's gangrene) or the scrotum (Fournier's gangrene).
  • Pathophysiology:
    • A mixed infection caused by both aerobic (e.g., staphylococci, coliforms) and anaerobic organisms (e.g., Bacteroides spp., Peptostreptococci).
    • The aerobic organisms destroy living tissue, creating an environment for anaerobic organisms to thrive.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Pain: Severe pain out of proportion to the physical findings.
    • Signs: Crepitus, foul-smelling discharge, and rapidly spreading infection.
    • The Finger Test: Lack of bleeding and minimal resistance when probing the deep fascia with a sterile glove, indicating necrotizing fasciitis.
  • Management:
    • Immediate surgical debridement: Wide excision of all necrotic tissue is crucial for survival.
    • Antibiotics: Broad spectrum IV antibiotics targeting both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.
    • Supportive care: Aggressive fluid resuscitation and circulatory support.
    • If untreated, it leads to multisystem organ failure and death.

Option A. IV antibiotics and observation: Incorrect. IV antibiotics alone are insufficient without surgical debridement in cases of necrotizing fasciitis.

Option B. Wide surgical debridement with broad spectrum antibiotics: Correct. Immediate and aggressive surgical debridement combined with broad spectrum antibiotics is essential for managing necrotizing fasciitis.

Option C. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Incorrect. While hyperbaric oxygen can be used as adjunctive therapy, it is not the primary treatment.

Option D. Local wound care and pain management: Incorrect. Local wound care without aggressive debridement is not appropriate for necrotizing fasciitis

Key Points:

  • Necrotizing fasciitis is a surgical emergency requiring immediate debridement and broad spectrum antibiotics.
  • The "finger test" is a diagnostic tool where minimal resistance to dissection suggests deep tissue involvement.

Tags:

  • Topic: Synergistic Spreading Gangrene (Necrotising Fasciitis)
  • Difficulty Level: Must Know

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 5 , Pages 58

questions.text: The following tests are used to check the efficiency of pasteurization of milk except
questions.solution:
• Methylene Blue Reduction Test is not a direct measure of pasteurization efficiency. It assesses the overall quality and microbial load of milk, indicating the presence of bacteria but not specifically the effectiveness of the pasteurization process.
  • The other tests serve as indicators of pasteurization effectiveness:
    • Phosphatase Test: Checks for residual enzyme activity; positive results indicate incomplete pasteurization.
    • Standard Plate Count: Measures the total viable bacterial count, reflecting overall microbial quality.
    • Coliform Count: Determines fecal contamination, with low counts expected post-pasteurization.

Why Not Others:

  • A (Phosphatase test): Essential for confirming pasteurization efficiency; a positive result indicates the process was ineffective.
  • B (Standard plate count): Useful for assessing bacterial load; high counts suggest insufficient pasteurization.
  • C (Coliform count): Indicates sanitary quality; presence suggests failure in pasteurization or contamination.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Methylene Blue Reduction Test assesses milk quality but does not directly evaluate pasteurization efficiency, unlike phosphatase, standard plate count, and coliform count tests.

choices.text: It is written by the advocate of the dying person
The person should be of sound disposing mind
The person (testator) must sign the will in presence of two witnesses
It should not be made under any influence of any person

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about Holograph will?
questions.solution:
• Holograph Will:
    • Definition: A will that is entirely handwritten and signed by the testator (the person making the will).
    • Misconception: It is not written by an advocate or any other person.

Conditions for a Valid Holograph Will:

  • Sound Disposing Mind: The testator must be of sound mind, understanding the nature and implications of the will.
  • Signature: The testator must sign the will. (Note: It does not need witnesses in the case of holograph wills, but must be written and signed by the testator alone.)
  • Free from Influence: The will must be made voluntarily, without undue influence from others.

Validity Under Special Circumstances:

  • Can be made by individuals who may normally lack capacity (e.g., deaf, dumb, blind, or during lucid intervals of mental illness).

Invalidity:

  • Invalid if made by someone who is imbecile, intoxicated, or under delusions, as they lack the capability for rational judgment.

Why Not Others:

  • B) Sound disposing mind: This is essential for the validity of any will.
  • C) Sign in presence of two witnesses: This is true for most wills but not applicable for holograph wills, as they do not require witnesses.
  • D) No undue influence: This is a necessary condition for a valid will.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding Holograph Wills: Essential for ensuring that wills are valid and reflect the true intentions of the testator.
  • Legal Implications: Knowledge of the requirements can prevent disputes and ensure compliance with legal standards in estate planning.

Tags: good to know

Reference: Gautam Biswas - Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 6th Edition, Chapter 28, Page 481

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with Uterine tumor, Beta-hCG 100,000 IU/L, No fetal parts. Histology shows Sheets of cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast, Absence of villi. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. The patient's clinical presentation and histological findings are characteristic of choriocarcinoma:
  2. Uterine tumor: Choriocarcinoma typically arises in the uterus.
  3. Beta-hCG 100,000 IU/L: Elevated beta-hCG is a hallmark of choriocarcinoma.
  4. No fetal parts: Choriocarcinoma is a trophoblastic neoplasm without fetal tissue.
  5. Histology:
    • Sheets of cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast: Diagnostic feature of choriocarcinoma.
    • Absence of villi: Distinguishes choriocarcinoma from hydatidiform mole.

B. Hydatidiform mole:

  • Characterized by villi with hydropic degeneration.
  • Typically has lower beta-hCG levels.

C. Placental site trophoblastic tumor:

  • Arises from placental bed trophoblasts.
  • Typically has lower beta-hCG levels.

D. Invasive mole:

  • Characterized by villi invading myometrium.
  • Typically has lower beta-hCG levels.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 972.

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of noncaseating granuloma except:
questions.solution:
Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection which shows Caseating granuloma.

A caseous granuloma is a type of chronic inflammatory response characterized by a necrotic center (caseation) surrounded by immune cells. It is often associated with infections like tuberculosis (TB) caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Histopathology:

  • Necrotic Core: The central area of a caseous granuloma contains necrotic tissue with a cheese-like (caseous) appearance, hence the name.
  • Macrophages: Around the core are activated macrophages, also known as epithelioid cells, which form a tight cluster.
  • Giant Cells: These are multinucleated cells formed by the fusion of macrophages, often seen at the periphery of the granuloma.
  • Lymphocytes: Surrounding the macrophages and giant cells are T-lymphocytes, which mediate the immune response.
  • Fibrosis: Over time, fibrous tissue may form around the granuloma as part of the healing process.

Caseous granulomas are most commonly associated with tuberculosis, but they can also occur in other conditions like fungal infections (e.g., histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis), syphilis, and sarcoidosis.

Mechanism:
The body forms granulomas as an attempt to contain and isolate pathogens that are difficult to eradicate, such as mycobacteria. T-helper cells (Th1) release interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), activating macrophages to form granulomas.

Incorrect Options:

Non-caseating granulomas are a type of granulomatous inflammation that lack central necrosis (caseation). These granulomas are typically seen in a variety of diseases, often of immune or inflammatory origin.

Options A,B & D : All are the examples of Non caseating granuloma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Caseating granuloma is seen in histoplasmosis.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 100.

questions.text: A 78 year old man with diabetic autonomic neuropathy brought to the medicine department with complaints of dizziness and fainting when arising from bed in the morning. Which of the following drugs would be most beneficial to this patient?
questions.solution:
• Midodrine is a selective α 1-adrenoceptor agonist that is used to treat postural (orthostatic) hypotension.
  • Midodrine :
    • Midodrine is an orally effective α1 receptor agonist. It is a prodrug, converted to an active metabolite, desglymidodrine, which achieves peak concentrations about 1 h after a dose of midodrine.
    • Midodrine-induced rises in blood pressure are associated with contraction of both arterial and venous smooth muscle.
    • This is advantageous in the treatment of patients with autonomic insufficiency and postural hypotension.
    • A frequent complication in these patients is supine hypertension.

Option A: Dobutamine acts mainly on β adrenergic receptors, and is a weak α agonist. The only prominent action of clinically employed doses (2-8 μg/kg/min i.v. infusion) is increased force of cardiac contraction and output, without significant change in peripheral resistance and BP.

Option B: Salbutamol (albuterol)and terbutaline are fast acting drugs by inhalation route, so they are used for aborting an attack of acute asthma.

Option D: Clonidine is α2 agonist and decreases the central sympathetic outflow. It decreases blood pressure as well as heart rate.

Key Takeaway:

  • Midodrine is a selective α 1-adrenoceptor agonist that is used to treat postural (orthostatic) hypotension.

  • Midodrine
  • Good to know

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the ophthalmology clinic by her parents due to complaints of blurred vision while watching television and difficulty reading the board at school. Her family history reveals that both parents are myopic. On examination, her visual acuity is 20/50 in the right eye and 20/40 in the left eye, which improves to 20/20 with the use of corrective lenses. A comprehensive eye exam reveals an axial length of 26.5 mm in the right eye and 26.0 mm in the left eye. Based on the findings, which of the following types of myopia is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
MYOPIA

  • Types of Myopia:
    • Simple Myopia: The most common type, often hereditary, characterized by an axial length that is slightly longer than normal without significant pathological changes. Typically, the refractive error is less than -6.00 D.
    • Pathological Myopia: Associated with high levels of myopia (usually greater than -6.00 D) and characterized by elongation of the eyeball. It has an increased risk of complications such as retinal detachment, chorioretinal degeneration, and macular changes.
    • Degenerative Myopia: A severe form of pathological myopia, typically seen in adults, characterized by significant structural changes in the retina and choroid leading to visual impairment.
    • Pseudomyopia: A temporary condition caused by spasm of accommodation, often in young people, resulting in symptoms similar to myopia but reversible with proper management.

Management and Implications:

  • Correction: Appropriate glasses or contact lenses for visual acuity.
  • Regular Monitoring: Especially for pathological and degenerative myopia, to detect potential complications early.
  • Lifestyle Adjustments: Encouragement of outdoor activities and reduced screen time to mitigate progression in children.

Why not other options :

  • A) Simple myopia: Correct. Simple myopia is the most common type, typically associated with a refractive error under -6.00 D and slightly increased axial length without significant pathology. The patient's age, family history, and corrective response align with this type.
  • B) Pathological myopia: Incorrect. Pathological myopia involves higher myopia (usually > -6.00 D), often with risks like retinal degeneration and detachment. Although the axial length is slightly increased, no pathological changes are noted, making this unlikely.
  • C) Degenerative myopia: Incorrect. This severe form often occurs in adults with structural retinal changes, such as chorioretinal atrophy, leading to visual impairment. It's not applicable to this young patient with no degenerative findings.
  • D) Pseudomyopia: Incorrect. Pseudomyopia results from accommodation spasm, producing reversible myopic symptoms. Unlike simple myopia, it is temporary and not due to structural eye changes.

Key Takeaways

  • Simple Myopia:
    • Definition: Common type, often hereditary, characterized by increased axial length without major pathology.
    • Clinical Features: Blurred distance vision, correctable with lenses, often < -6.00 D refractive error.
    • Management: Corrective lenses, lifestyle modifications (outdoor activity), and regular follow-up to monitor progression.

Reference: Parson's diseases of eye-22nd edition section II chapter 8 page 71-75.

questions.text: A newborn presents with exposed abdominal contents at birth. The intestines are not covered by a sac and are protruding to the right of the umbilical cord. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Major Difference between Exomphalos & Gastroschisis

Option A: Gastroschisis is characterised by intestines protruding through a defect to the right of the umbilical cord without a covering sac. hence Option A Is Correct.

Option B: Omphalocele involves abdominal contents protruding through the umbilical cord covered by a sac.

Option C: Umbilical hernia involves protrusion through the umbilical ring, covered by skin.

Option D: Diaphragmatic hernia involves abdominal contents herniating into the thorax, not externally.

Key Takeaways:

  • Gastroschisis: Defect to the right of the umbilical cord, no sac.
  • Omphalocele: Defect at the umbilical cord, covered by a sac.
  • Management: Both require surgical intervention; omphaloceles may need staged repair due to associated anomalies.

  • DIFFICULTY: MUST KNOW
  • PYQ: NEET 2020, FMGE Dec 2020

choices.text: It contains estradiol valerate instead of ethinyl estradiol
It is an estrogen step-down & progestin step-up regime
Can be freely used in women with history of thromboembolic events

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true about 'Qlaira', the new generation oral contraceptive?
questions.solution:
• Qlaira is a quadriphasic contraceptive which uses estradiol valerate (OPTION A) and dienogest (OPTION B)
  • It is a novel combined oral contraceptive (COC) for continuous administration, with a complex quadriphasic dose regimen
  • It is an estrogen step-down & progestin step-up regime (OPTION C)

Estrogen Step-Down

  • Initial Higher Dose: The regimen starts with a higher dose of estrogen in the early part of the cycle. This provides a robust hormonal environment similar to the natural menstrual cycle's early phase.
  • Gradual Reduction: Over the course of the cycle, the estrogen dose gradually decreases. This step-down approach mimics the natural decline in estrogen levels that occurs later in the menstrual cycle.

Progestin Step-Up

  • Initial Lower Dose: At the start of the cycle, the progestin component (dienogest) is administered in lower doses.
  • Gradual Increase: As the cycle progresses, the dose of progestin is increased. This step-up approach is designed to enhance the endometrial lining's protection against pregnancy and to support the hormonal balance as the cycle advances.

Qlaira is designed to closely mimic the natural hormonal changes that occur during a menstrual cycle, using a step-down approach for estrogen and a step-up approach for progestin. This unique formulation helps to manage hormone levels in a way that closely resembles the body's natural fluctuations, potentially leading to a more natural and balanced menstrual cycle experience.

  • It is contraindicated in women with prior history of a thromboembolic phenomenon (Hence OPTION D is the incorrect statement)

KEY TAKEAWAY: Qlaira is a combined hormonal contraceptive (CHC) that, like other CHCs, is associated with an increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE).

  • Type: Good to know
  • Topic: Recent advances in hormonal contraception

questions.text: Modified biophysical profile consists of:
questions.solution:
The Modified Biophysical Profile (MBPP) is used to assess fetal well-being by combining two components:

a. AFI & NST

Components of MBPP:

  1. Non-Stress Test (NST):
    • Purpose: Measures fetal heart rate response to fetal movements.
    • Procedure: The mother is connected to a fetal heart rate monitor to track the fetal heart rate over time, usually for 20-40 minutes. A reactive NST shows at least two accelerations of the fetal heart rate (at least 15 beats per minute above the baseline) in a 20-minute period.
  2. Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI):
    • Purpose: Assesses the amount of amniotic fluid, which can be an indicator of fetal health and well-being.
    • Procedure: AFI is determined through a transabdominal ultrasound, where the uterus is divided into four quadrants, and the deepest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid in each quadrant is measured and summed.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

The MBPP is a valuable tool for evaluating fetal health in a more streamlined manner, focusing on the NST and AFI to provide essential information on fetal well-being.

  • Type: Must know
  • Topic: Modified Biophysical Profile
  • PYQ: INICET NEET FMGE

Reference: DC Dutta Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition, Chapter 11 Antenatal Assessment of Fetal Well-Being, Page no. 122

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with unexplained weight loss, hyperpigmentation of the skin, and weakness. His laboratory tests show an elevated 24-hour urinary cortisol and a plasma ACTH level of 80 pg/mL. A high-dose dexamethasone suppression test reveals no suppression of cortisol levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with signs of Cushing's syndrome (elevated cortisol) and high ACTH levels (>80 pg/mL), suggesting ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome.
  • The lack of cortisol suppression on the high-dose dexamethasone test points to ectopic ACTH production, commonly caused by tumors such as small-cell lung cancer.
  • Cushing's disease (B) would typically show suppression of cortisol with high-dose dexamethasone.
  • Adrenal adenomas (A) and primary adrenal hyperplasia (D) cause ACTH-independent Cushing's syndrome, associated with low ACTH levels.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ectopic ACTH production is characterized by high ACTH and no suppression with high-dose dexamethasone.

  • Topic: Endocrinology - Ectopic ACTH Syndrome
  • Difficulty Level: Good to Know
  • PYQ Reference: NEET PG 2018
