choices.text: It is also called Caffey-Kempe syndrome
More common with female children below 3 years of age
Infantile whiplash syndrome is an example
Often injuries in different stages of healing are found

questions.text: Which of the following sentences is FALSE regarding Battered Baby Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Battered Baby Syndrome Overview:

  • Definition: A condition where a child suffers repeated physical injuries due to non-accidental violence by a parent or guardian.
  • Also Known As: Caffey syndrome, Caffey-Kempe syndrome, maltreatment syndrome, or parent-infant traumatic stress syndrome-often missed as a cause of pediatric trauma.

Key Points:

  • Age: Majority of cases occur in children below 3 years of age.
  • Sex: More common in male children (M ratio is 2:1).
  • Child Status: Frequently involves illegitimate or unwanted children, often the eldest or youngest, sometimes with mental subnormality.
  • Parental History: Parents often provide vague explanations for injuries, such as falls, that do not match the injury severity or timing.
  • Medical Attention: Parents tend to seek help late when the child's condition becomes serious.
  • Healing Stages: Injuries in different stages of healing are commonly observed, indicating repeated trauma.
  • CNS Injuries: Caused by actions like throwing, striking, or shaking the infant (shaken baby syndrome or infantile whiplash syndrome), leading to intracranial hemorrhage.

Why Not Others:

  • A) True: It is also known as Caffey-Kempe syndrome.
  • B) False: Battered Baby Syndrome is more common in male children below 3 years of age.
  • C) True: Infantile whiplash syndrome is indeed an example of the syndrome.
  • D) True: Injuries in different stages of healing are often found.

Key Takeaways:

  • Battered Baby Syndrome is characterized by repeated physical injuries from non-accidental violence, predominantly affecting male children under 3 years of age.
  • Parents typically provide inconsistent explanations for injuries, and medical attention is often delayed until the child's condition worsens.

Tags: neet 2022

Reference: Gautam Biswas - Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 6th Edition, Chapter 20, Page no. 33-374

questions.text: An investigator is studying the interaction between a new drug B and an existing drug A. The results are recorded and plotted on the graph shown. Which of the following properties of drug B best explain the observed effect on the dose-response curve of drug A?
questions.solution:
• Competitive antagonists block the binding site of the drugs that they antagonize and would cause the original dose-response curve to shift to the right reflecting a decrease in potency.

Option A:

Non-competitive antagonists can either cause a conformational change or bind to the active site of the receptor allosterically.

This decreases the binding of the agonist, which cannot be overcome by increasing doses of the agonist.

Option C:

An inverse agonist would bind to the same receptor but has a different binding site than an agonist and typically elicits the opposite of the agonistic effect.

Option D:

A full agonist would have the same potency and efficacy as the original drug. Therefore, the dose-response curve would remain unchanged.

Key Takeaway

  • DRC can be utilized to know whether a drug is competitive or noncompetitive inhibitor.
  • In case of competitive inhibitor, curve will shift to right, i.e. now the same agonist will have less potency in the presence of antagonist. It does not affect the efficacy.
  • In case of noncompetitive inhibitor, there will be flattening of DRC, i.e. efficacy decreases. It usually does not affect potency.
  • If the antagonist is irreversible competitive, then there will be decrease in potency as well as efficacy.

Tags:

  • Competitive Antagonist
  • Good to know
  • Neet 2018 / inicet may 2022 / fmge Aug 2020

The patient's clinical presentation and tumor characteristics point to a Triple-negative/Basal-like breast cancer subtype:

  3. ER/PR/HER2-negative: Triple-negative status.
  4. CK5/6-positive: Basal marker expression.

questions.text: The method of choice for removal of organs of HIV positive dead body is
questions.solution:
• Rokitansky's method: This technique involves dissecting the organs in situ (in their original position), making it the preferred choice for bodies with highly transmissible diseases like HIV and hepatitis B, as it minimizes exposure risk during organ removal.
  • Virchow's method: Involves removing organs one by one, disrupting anatomical relationships, which is useful for assessing individual organ pathology but increases the risk of exposure.
  • Lettule's method: Involves en masse removal of organs while keeping all attachments intact, which may not be ideal for highly infectious cases.
  • Ghon's method: Involves en bloc removal of organs according to systems, but it does not specifically address the safety concerns with highly transmissible infections.

Why Not Others:

  • a. Virchow's method: Increased risk due to separate handling of organs.
  • b. Lettule's method: Although it removes organs intact, it poses a higher risk of exposure during removal.
  • d. Ghon's method: While systematic, it does not prioritize safety for transmissible infections.

Key takeaways:

  • Rokitansky's method is the safest and most effective technique for organ removal in cases of HIV and other transmissible diseases.
  • Other methods increase exposure risk, making them less suitable for such situations.

Tags: fmge dec 2021

Reference: Gautam Biswas - Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 6th Edition, Chapter 7, Page no. 126

choices.text: Give only DT (Diphtheria and Tetanus) vaccine

questions.text: An infant develops convulsions after the administration of DPT vaccine, what should be the course of action for subsequent doses?
questions.solution:
The correct course of action for subsequent doses after an infant develops convulsions following the administration of the DPT vaccine is:

C. Give only DT (Diphtheria and Tetanus) vaccine

  • Reason for Switching to DT Vaccine: After adverse reactions like convulsions following DPT, DT vaccine is recommended as it excludes the pertussis component (the primary source of neurological side effects) while still providing protection against diphtheria and tetanus.
  • Pertussis Component Caution: The pertussis component in DPT is known to trigger more frequent and severe side effects, such as high fever and convulsions, especially in infants with neurological sensitivity.
  • Importance of Continued Immunization: Discontinuing immunization altogether would leave the infant at risk of diphtheria and tetanus, both of which are life-threatening conditions.
  • DT vs. DPT in High-Risk Cases: DT is the vaccine of choice in high-risk cases (e.g., those with previous seizures or encephalopathy following DPT), as it balances safety with disease prevention.

Why Not Other Options?

  • A. Discontinue the vaccination of DPT: Omitting vaccination entirely is unsafe; DT vaccine can be safely given without the pertussis component.
  • B. Give only diphtheria vaccine: This does not provide protection against tetanus, which is critical for infants.
  • D. Give only TT (Tetanus) vaccine: While tetanus is covered, this leaves the infant vulnerable to diphtheria, a serious respiratory infection.

Key Takeaways:

  • For infants with adverse reactions to DPT, DT vaccine offers a safe alternative by excluding pertussis while ensuring protection against diphtheria and tetanus, maintaining immunity without the risk of further complications.

Tags: neet 2022

Reference: Immunization_Handbook_for_Medical_Officers 2017, MOHFW, GOI, unit no.-04 , Page No -19-26.,Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition

questions.text: Chronic kidney disease with normal kidney size is seen in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
• Normal kidney size in the context of chronic kidney disease (CKD) can indicate acute or subacute conditions rather than long-standing damage.
  • Chronic interstitial nephritis is characterized by progressive scarring of the renal interstitium, typically resulting in reduced kidney size over time due to fibrosis.
  • Exceptions where kidney size may remain normal despite CKD include:
    • Diabetic nephropathy: Initially, kidneys can be enlarged due to hyperfiltration and increased glomerular volume, but they may become small in later stages of the disease.
    • Amyloidosis: The kidneys can maintain a normal size even as function deteriorates due to amyloid deposition affecting glomerular function without causing significant enlargement or reduction.
    • HIV nephropathy: This condition may also present with normal kidney size in CKD due to direct viral effects on renal parenchyma and associated immune responses without significant hypertrophy or atrophy.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Diabetic nephropathy: Initially presents with enlarged kidneys before progressing to CKD.
  • C. Amyloidosis: May also have normal kidney size in the context of CKD.
  • D. HIV nephropathy: Can maintain normal kidney size while having CKD.

Key Takeaways:

  • Chronic kidney disease with normal kidney size is often observed in diabetic nephropathy, amyloidosis, and HIV nephropathy, but not in chronic interstitial nephritis.
  • Normal kidney size may indicate a more acute process or specific conditions, while shrunken kidneys suggest long-standing CKD.

Tags:

  • Topic: Chronic kidney disease
  • Type: Good to Know
  • Difficulty: Easy
  • PYQ: NEET PG 2021

questions.text: The microscopic image demonstrates sclerotic bodies. What condition is primarily associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
• Septate hyphae: Found in fungi like Aspergillus and Penicillium but not in Mucor, which has non-septate hyphae.
  • Broad, non-septate hyphae: Correct. Mucor species exhibit broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae, typically branching at right angles (90°), which is a key diagnostic feature.
  • Chlamydoconidia: Thick-walled resting spores produced by other fungi like Candida, not seen in Mucor.
  • Yeast cells: Mucor exists as filamentous hyphae, not in yeast form, which is characteristic of Candida and other yeast-forming fungi.

Additional Points:

  • Mucor species are rapidly growing molds found in soil and decaying organic matter.
  • The infection, mucormycosis, typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals, affecting the sinuses, lungs, and brain.
  • Histopathological examination reveals broad, non-septate hyphae infiltrating tissue, a hallmark of the disease.

Key Takeaway:

  • Broad, non-septate hyphae and right-angle branching are key diagnostic features of Mucor species, commonly seen in invasive infections like mucormycosis.

choices.text: Incision and drainage of the abscess

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with sudden-onset pain, redness, and swelling near the medial canthus of the right eye. She reports difficulty opening her eye due to the swelling. On examination, there is tenderness over the lacrimal sac, with associated erythema and a purulent discharge upon pressure. There is no proptosis or limitation of eye movements. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Dacryocystitis is an infection of the lacrimal sac, typically secondary to an obstruction in the nasolacrimal duct. It can be categorized into acute and chronic forms.

Acute Dacryocystitis

Causes:

  • Primary: Nasolacrimal duct obstruction (most common), leading to stasis of tears and secondary bacterial infection.
  • Secondary causes: Nasal or sinus infections, trauma to the lacrimal system, or rarely, tumors compressing the nasolacrimal duct.

Clinical Features:

  • Sudden-onset pain, swelling, redness, and tenderness over the medial canthus (lacrimal sac area).
  • Erythema and induration overlying the lacrimal sac.
  • Purulent discharge may be expressed with pressure over the lacrimal sac.
  • Systemic symptoms: Fever, malaise in severe cases.

Complications:

  • If untreated, it can lead to an abscess, cellulitis, or spread to orbital cellulitis.

Management:

  1. Antibiotics:
    • Topical antibiotics: Ciprofloxacin, Ofloxacin.
    • Systemic antibiotics: Oral amoxicillin-clavulanic acid or cefuroxime to cover both gram-positive and gram-negative organisms.
    • Duration: Usually 7-10 days.
  2. Warm compresses: Helps with pain relief and reducing inflammation.
  3. Abscess formation: If present, incision and drainage of the abscess are necessary.
  4. Surgical intervention: Definitive treatment with dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) should be delayed until the acute infection resolves.

Chronic Dacryocystitis

Causes:

  • Chronic nasolacrimal duct obstruction (due to fibrosis or inflammation) is the most common cause.
  • Other causes include previous episodes of acute dacryocystitis, trauma, sinus diseases, or tumors.

Clinical Features:

  • Chronic tearing (epiphora) due to a blocked nasolacrimal duct.
  • Mild swelling over the medial canthus, usually non-tender.
  • Mucoid or purulent discharge from the puncta may be expressed.
  • Less pain and swelling compared to the acute form.

Management:

  1. Conservative treatment: For some mild cases, warm compresses and massage of the lacrimal sac can help.
  2. Antibiotics:
    • May be used if there is mild infection or discharge, though chronic cases often require surgical correction.
  3. Definitive treatment:
    • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is the gold standard for managing chronic dacryocystitis. It involves creating a new passageway between the lacrimal sac and nasal cavity to bypass the blocked nasolacrimal duct.
    • External DCR: A small incision is made on the side of the nose to perform the surgery.
    • Endonasal DCR: A less invasive option performed via the nasal cavity with the help of an endoscope

Treatment Summary

  1. Acute Dacryocystitis:
    • Initial management: Topical and oral antibiotics (broad-spectrum).
    • Supportive care: Warm compresses.
    • If abscess: Incision and drainage.
    • Definitive treatment: DCR surgery after infection resolves.
  2. Chronic Dacryocystitis:
    • Initial management: Conservative management with antibiotics and massage.
    • Definitive treatment:

Why Not Others:

  • A. Immediate lacrimal sac surgery: Surgery is not recommended in the acute phase; it's performed after infection resolution.
  • C. Lacrimal probing and syringing: Contraindicated during acute infection due to the risk of spreading bacteria.
  • D. Incision and drainage of the abscess: Reserved only for cases with a confirmed abscess formation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Acute dacryocystitis is managed with topical and oral antibiotics to address the infection.
  • Surgery is delayed until the infection resolves to prevent complications like cellulitis.

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Saunders Elsevier; 2015. p. 356-359.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents with a painless testicular mass. Ultrasound reveals a solid, heterogeneous tumor. Histopathological examination shows:
Papillary and glandular patterns
Hyaline droplets and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) positivity
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Image shown above is of Schiller duval body, which resembles endodermal sinuses, consist of a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells resembling primitive glomeruli.

B. Papillary and glandular pattern, elevated AFP level, age of the patient and an image of Schiller Duval body lead to a diagnosis of prepubertal yolk sac tumor.

Option A: Embryonal carcinoma : Embryonal carcinoma is a relatively uncommon type of nonseminomatous germ cell tumor that occurs in the ovaries and testes.

Micrograph of an embryonal carcinoma showing its typical features - prominent nucleoli, marked nuclear atypia, necrosis, and nuclear overlap.

Option C: Teratoma: A teratoma is a tumor made up of several types of tissue, such as hair, muscle, teeth, or bone.

Option D: Leydig cell tumor: Due to excess testosterone secreted by the tumor, one-third of female patients present with a recent history of progressive masculinization. Masculinization is preceded by anovulation, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea and defeminization. Additional signs include acne and hirsutism, voice deepening, clitoromegaly, temporal hair recession, and an increase in musculature. Serum testosterone level is high.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 972.

questions.text: The rat hole appearance in Shotgun wound is seen from which range?
questions.solution:
1. Type of Appearance Identified:
    • The rat hole appearance in shotgun wounds is specifically seen at the mid/near range (up to 7 feet).
  2. Characteristics of Mid/Near Range Wounds:
    • Wound Formation: At mid range, shot enters the body in a single mass, creating a round hole.
    • Wound Edges: The edges of the wound are abraded and crenated/scalloped, resembling a cookie cutter effect.
    • Tattooing: This may be visible up to 3-4 feet, indicating the range without burning or soot.
  3. Wound Characteristics by Range:
    • Contact Shot: Causes extensive destruction, particularly on the head, with circular wounds having seared and blackened edges due to hot gases.
    • Close Range: Similar to contact wounds, often leading to severe mutilation, especially in head wounds.
    • Long Range: Beyond 7 feet, results in multiple pellet wounds surrounding a central wound with no significant tissue disruption.

(Why Not Others):

  • A. Contact shot:
    • Results in severe destruction and circular wounds with burnt edges, not the rat hole appearance.
  • B. Close range:
    • Wounds are highly mutilating, resembling contact wounds but do not present the rat hole effect.
  • D. Long range:
    • Characterized by multiple pellet wounds surrounding a central area without the cookie cutter effect.

Key Takeaway:

The rat hole appearance is distinctive of mid/near range shotgun wounds, formed by a single mass entry of shot, while other ranges exhibit different wound characteristics and patterns.

Tags: fmge July 2023

Reference: Gautam Biswas - Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, 6th Edition, Chapter 12, Page no. 245-246

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with burns involving his anterior torso, left upper limb, and entire right lower limb. Using the rule of nines, what is the estimated total body surface area (TBSA) burned?
questions.solution:
Using the rule of nines:

Anterior torso (chest and abdomen) = 18%

Left upper limb = 9%

Entire right lower limb = 18%

Total TBSA = 18% + 9% + 18% = 45%

  • Alternative Methods:
  • Patient's palm (wrist to fingertips) represents approximately 1% TBSA for small burns (<10%).

Limitations:

  • Rule of nines may overestimate burn size in obese patients.

Key Points:

  • The rule of nines is an effective, quick method to assess burn size in adults, but not suitable for children under 10 years old.Accurate burn size estimation is critical for guiding fluid resuscitation decisions.

TAGS:

  • Difficulty Level: Good to Know
  • Topic: Rule of nine
  • PYQ: NEETPG 2022

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a non-healing ulcer on his leg. Upon examination, the ulcer has an undermined edge. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ulcers and Sinuses

  • Ulcers: Discontinuity of epithelial surfaces. Classified as non-specific (shelving edge), specific (e.g., tuberculous with undermined edges), and malignant (e.g., basal cell carcinoma with a rolled edge).
  • Sinuses: Blind-ending tracts often resulting from abscesses. May be congenital (due to embryonic remnants) or acquired (e.g., from foreign bodies or infections).
  • Fistulas: Tracts connecting two epithelial surfaces, such as colocutaneous fistulas.

Option A) Non-specific ulcers have a shelving edge.

Option B) Correct. Tuberculous ulcers are characterised by undermined edges.

Option C) Basal cell carcinoma (rodent ulcer) presents with a rolled edge, often with visible blood vessels.

Option D) Syphilitic ulcers have a punched-out edge with a thin base covered by a "wash-leather" slough.

Key Points:

Tuberculous ulcers have undermined edges.non-specific ulcers have shelving edges.

TAGS:

Difficulty Level: Must Know

Topic: Ulcers and Sinuses

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 45, Pages-663

choices.text: Tumour size of 8 cm confined to the kidney

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for partial nephrectomy in renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Indications for Partial Nephrectomy

  • Indications:
    • small tumours (<4 cm),(4-7 CM IN SELECTED CASES)
    • bilateral renal tumours,
    • tumours in a solitary kidney,
    • when nephron sparing is necessary due to other medical conditions.

Advantages: Preservation of renal function, reduced risk of chronic kidney disease, and decreased likelihood of needing dialysis.

Contraindications: Large tumours (>7 cm), locally advanced tumours, and when complete resection cannot be safely achieved.

Option A : Tumour size of 8 cm confined to the kidney is Incorrect. Radical nephrectomy is typically preferred for tumours >7 cm.

Option B : Partial nephrectomy is indicated to preserve renal function when tumours are present in both kidneys Hence Option B is Correct.

Option C : Systemic therapy is usually the mainstay for metastatic RCC, not partial nephrectomy.

Option D : Patients with poor performance status may not tolerate surgery; other less invasive options or palliative care might be considered.

Key Takeaway:

  • Partial nephrectomy is indicated for small renal tumours or when both kidneys are affected.It aims to preserve renal function and prevent chronic kidney disease.

Tags:

Topic: Indications for Partial Nephrectomy

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

choices.text: Total Abdominal Hysterectomy (TAH) with Bilateral Salpingo-Oophorectomy (BSO)

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is diagnosed with Stage IIA cervical cancer. What type of hysterectomy is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Radical Hysterectomy is suitable for Stage II cervical cancer, involving removal of the uterus, cervix, upper part of the vagina, and pelvic lymphadenectomy. This procedure aims to remove all possible cancerous tissues and is the standard approach for this stage of cervical cancer.

OPTION A: Total Abdominal Hysterectomy (TAH) with Bilateral Salpingo-Oophorectomy (BSO) may be used for earlier stages but is not sufficient for Stage II malignancy without additional procedures.

OPTION C: Vaginal hysterectomy is not typically used for cancer treatment due to limitations in staging and removal.

OPTION D: Laparoscopic surgery is less commonly used for malignancies of this stage without additional procedures.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Radical hysterectomy is the preferred method for Stage IIA cervical cancer as it ensures comprehensive removal of cancerous tissues and allows for accurate staging.

Type: Must know

Topic: Radical hysterectomy

choices.text: At the level of the infundibulopelvic ligament
At the level of the cervix

questions.text: The most common site of ureteral injury during a pelvic surgery:
questions.solution:
Near the uterine artery: The ureter is most commonly injured near the uterine artery because of its close proximity and frequent manipulation during pelvic surgeries, particularly those involving the uterus and cervix.

OPTION A: At the level of the infundibulopelvic ligament: Although injury can occur here, it is less common compared to the area near the uterine artery. The infundibulopelvic ligament is more related to ovarian surgery.

OPTION B: Near the uterine artery: The ureter is most commonly injured near the uterine artery because of its close proximity and frequent manipulation during pelvic surgeries, particularly those involving the uterus and cervix.

OPTION C: At the level of the cervix ureteral injury can occur but its not very frequent. Mc common site is near the uterine artery.

D: At the ureterovesical junction: Injuries at the ureterovesical junction are more common in urological procedures rather than gynecological surgeries. This junction is less frequently involved in gynecological procedures compared to the area near the uterine artery.

KEY TAKEAWAY: The area near the uterine artery is a critical site for potential ureteral injury during gynecological surgeries due to anatomical proximity and surgical manipulation.

The phrase "water under the bridge" is often used in surgical contexts to describe the anatomical relationship between structures. For uterine artery and ureter injury, this phrase helps remember the relationship and common site of injury.

Here's how it applies to uterine artery and ureter injuries:

"Water Under the Bridge" Mnemonic

  • Water: Represents the Ureter.
  • Under: Represents the Uterine Artery as the "bridge" over the ureter.
  • The Bridge: Indicates that the uterine artery crosses over the ureter.

In pelvic surgery, particularly during hysterectomy or other gynecological procedures, the ureter runs underneath the uterine artery. The uterine artery crosses over the ureter, making it a common site for injury during surgical manipulation around the uterine artery.

Type: Must know

Topic: Common sites of ureteric injury in Gynaecological surgeries

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presents with a sudden onset of severe scrotal pain, swelling, and nausea. The affected testis is high riding with an absent cremasteric reflex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Torsion of Testes

  • Twisting of the spermatic cord leading to ischemia and necrosis if untreated.
  • Symptoms: Acute onset of severe scrotal pain, swelling, nausea, vomiting, high riding testis, absent cremasteric reflex.
  • Diagnosis: Primarily clinical; Doppler ultrasound to confirm blood flow disruption.
  • Management: Surgical detorsion and fixation (orchidopexy) within 6 hours to save the testis.
  • Bilateral orchidopexy advised.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Epididymitis: Incorrect. Epididymitis is usually associated with gradual pain, fever, and urinary symptoms, with a positive cremasteric reflex.

Option B. Testicular torsion: Correct. Sudden severe pain, highriding testis, and absence of the cremasteric reflex are classic signs of testicular torsion.

Option C. Hydrocele: Incorrect. Hydrocele typically presents with painless scrotal swelling.

Option D. Varicocele: Incorrect. Varicocele causes a dull ache and "bag of worms" appearance, not acute pain and swelling.

Key Points:

  • Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency requiring prompt intervention.
  • High riding testis and absent cremasteric reflex are diagnostic clues.

Tags:

Topic: Torsion of Testes

Difficulty Level: Must Know

PYQ: FMGE JUNE 2021

questions.text: A 25 year old male presents to the emergency department after a fall onto a metal bar, complaining of perineal pain and difficulty urinating. On examination, there is "butterfly shaped" bruising in the perineum, and the patient has a high riding prostate on digital rectal examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bulbar Urethral Injury

  • Cause:
    • Typically results from straddle type injuries (e.g., falling on a bicycle bar) or direct trauma to the perineum.
  • Symptoms:
    • Perineal pain, difficulty urinating, blood at the urethral meatus, and perineal bruising ("butterfly sign").
  • Diagnosis:
    • Retrograde urethrogram (RUG) to assess the integrity of the urethra.
  • Management:
    • Initial catheterization to drain the bladder
    • surgical repair may be needed for complete tears.

Option A : Anterior urethral injury is Incorrect. Anterior urethral injuries usually involve the penile urethra and present with penile swelling or bleeding at the urethral meatus.

Option B : Bladder rupture is Incorrect. Bladder rupture typically involves suprapubic pain and is often associated with pelvic fractures.

Option C : Bulbar urethral injury is Correct. Bulbar urethral injuries occur commonly due to straddle injuries and can present with perineal bruising, pain, and a high riding prostate on examination.

Option D : Prostatic urethral injury is Incorrect. Prostatic urethral injuries are more often associated with pelvic fractures and high impact trauma.

Key Takeaway:

  • Bulbar urethral injuries are commonly caused by blunt perineal trauma.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by retrograde urethrogram.

Tags:

Topic : Bulbar Urethral Injury

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

choices.text: Direct communication between the internal carotid artery and the cavernous sinus
Rupture of the posterior communicating artery into the cavernous sinus
Venous thrombosis of the superior ophthalmic vein
An aneurysm compressing the cavernous sinus

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of progressive redness, swelling, and pulsatile noise in her right eye following a recent head injury. On examination, there is marked conjunctival chemosis, proptosis, and a "bruit" over the right orbit. The right eye shows restricted extraocular movements and increased intraocular pressure (IOP). Fundoscopy reveals dilated retinal veins. A CT scan reveals an enlarged superior ophthalmic vein. Which of the following best describes the most likely pathophysiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Caroticocavernous fistula (CCF) occurs due to a direct connection between the internal carotid artery and the cavernous sinus, leading to high-pressure arterial blood entering the cavernous sinus, causing venous congestion, proptosis, and a pulsatile bruit. This condition commonly follows trauma, as seen in this patient with head injury.

Carotid Cavernous Fistula (CCF):

  • Etiology:
    • Traumatic: Most common, often due to skull base fractures involving the carotid artery.
    • Spontaneous: Can occur in individuals with vascular anomalies or connective tissue disorders.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Direct CCF: High-flow communication between the internal carotid artery and cavernous sinus (most common in traumatic cases).
    • Indirect CCF: Low-flow communication from dural branches of the internal or external carotid arteries into the cavernous sinus.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Ocular: Pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, diplopia, restricted eye movements (due to cranial nerve compression in the cavernous sinus), elevated IOP, and dilated retinal veins.
    • Auditory: Pulsatile bruit in the orbit or head.
    • Systemic: Headache and visual impairment in severe cases.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Imaging: CT/MRI may show an enlarged superior ophthalmic vein or cavernous sinus. Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis and assessing the type of fistula.
  • Management:
    • Endovascular treatment: Embolization or stenting is the preferred approach, especially for high-flow fistulas.
    • Observation: May be considered in low-flow fistulas if symptoms are mild.
    • Surgical: Reserved for cases where endovascular treatment fails or is not feasible.

Why Not Others:

  • B: Rupture of the posterior communicating artery does not explain the clinical signs of CCF, such as pulsatile bruit and proptosis.
  • C: Venous thrombosis of the superior ophthalmic vein leads to venous congestion but lacks the characteristic arterialized bruit of CCF.
  • D: An aneurysm compressing the cavernous sinus would cause cranial nerve deficits but not the typical signs of CCF like proptosis and bruit.

Key Takeaways:

  • CCF is characterized by arterial-venous communication in the cavernous sinus, resulting in pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, bruit, and dilated retinal veins. It commonly follows trauma and is confirmed by imaging.

Reference:

  • Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Saunders Elsevier; 2015. p. 684-686.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a history of severe acute pancreatitis four weeks ago. He now reports persistent abdominal discomfort and early satiety. A CT scan reveals a well-defined fluid collection adjacent to the pancreas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic Pseudocysts

  • A pancreatic pseudocyst is a collection of pancreatic juice enclosed by a wall of fibrous or granulation tissue, typically arising after an episode of acute pancreatitis or trauma.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with persistent abdominal pain, discomfort, early satiety, or even a palpable mass. More than half of pseudocysts communicate with the pancreatic duct.

Diagnosis:

  • Imaging: Ultrasound or CT scan typically shows a well-circumscribed fluid collection adjacent to the pancreas.
  • Differential: Must differentiate from other cystic lesions like cystic neoplasms. EUS with fluid aspiration for CEA levels and cytology helps differentiate.
  • Complications: Pseudocysts can rupture, become infected, or cause obstruction of adjacent structures. Larger pseudocysts (>6 cm) are less likely to resolve spontaneously and may require intervention.

Management:

  • Most pseudocysts resolve spontaneously.
  • Intervention: Required if the pseudocyst persists beyond 12 weeks, causes symptoms, or complications develop.
  • Surgical drainage: Most definitive, with low recurrence rates.

Explanation:

Option A) Acute peripancreatic fluid collection (APFC) typically occurs in the early stages of acute pancreatitis (within the first week), whereas a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more to form.

Option B) Pancreatic abscesses are rare and usually present with signs of infection such as fever, rather than just discomfort and early satiety.

Option C) Correct. A pancreatic pseudocyst is a fluid collection that develops after an episode of acute pancreatitis, usually more than 4 weeks later, and is defined by a well-formed wall of granulation or fibrous tissue.

Option D) Solid pseudopapillary neoplasms are rare pancreatic tumors and are unlikely in this clinical scenario.

Key Points:

A pseudocyst requires more than 4 weeks to form after an acute pancreatitis episode.

Tags:

Topic: Pancreatic Pseudocyst

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

choices.text: A retrosternal goiter is typically removed via a thoracotomy.
All retrosternal goiters require a sternotomy for removal.
Over 95% of retrosternal goitres can be removed transcervically.
Surgery should always be performed in elderly patients, regardless of symptoms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents with progressive dysphagia and mild shortness of breath. Imaging reveals a large retrosternal goiter extending into the superior mediastinum. Which of the following is most accurate regarding the management of retrosternal goitre?
questions.solution:
Retrosternal Goitre

  • A retrosternal goitre is a multinodular thyroid gland that grows into the mediastinum, potentially causing compression of surrounding structures.
  • Symptoms: Most patients are asymptomatic, but larger goiters can cause dysphagia, airway compression, and tracheal deviation.
  • Indications for Surgery:
    • Significant airway compression.
    • Symptomatic patients (dysphagia, dyspnea).
    • Young patients likely to develop symptoms.
  • Surgical Approach:
    • Transcervical Approach: Over 95% of retrosternal goiters can be removed transcervically.
    • Sternotomy: Required in <5% of cases, particularly for large or fixed goitres, or when malignant disease is suspected.
  • Preoperative Imaging: Cross-sectional imaging (CT) is crucial for assessing the extent of the goiter and planning the surgical approach.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. A thoracotomy is not the typical approach for retrosternal goiter removal. Most are removed through a transcervical approach.

Option B) Incorrect. Only a minority of retrosternal goiters require a sternotomy, specifically those with malignant disease or large goiters extending into the posterior mediastinum.

Option C) Correct. Over 95% of retrosternal goiters can be removed using a transcervical approach. Sternotomy is only needed in select cases, such as when the goiter is too large or fixed.

Option D) Incorrect. In elderly patients with incidentally discovered retrosternal goitres and no symptoms, observation is often the preferred approach rather than prophylactic surgery.

Key Points:

Most retrosternal goitres are removed transcervically.

Tags:

Topic: Retrosternal Goitre

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features are seen when seeds from the fruits given in the image are ingested?
questions.solution:
• Muttering Delirium: This condition is characterized by incoherent speech and altered mental status, often resulting from the anticholinergic effects of Datura. Patients may exhibit confusion, agitation, and hallucinations, which can lead to dangerous behavior.
  • Datura's Pharmacology: The seeds contain tropane alkaloids like atropine and scopolamine, which block the action of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, leading to a variety of physiological effects, including dilated pupils and decreased secretions.
  • Anticholinergic Symptoms: Other symptoms of Datura poisoning include dry mouth, increased heart rate (tachycardia), urinary retention, flushed skin, and decreased bowel sounds, all typical of anticholinergic toxicity.
  • Psychological Effects: The psychological manifestations can include hallucinations, agitation, and sometimes, violent behavior due to the profound CNS effects of the poison.

Why Not Other Options:

  • c. Pinpoint Pupils: This is indicative of opioid or cholinergic poisoning, where acetylcholine levels are elevated. In contrast, Datura ingestion leads to mydriasis (dilated pupils), due to its anticholinergic properties, as it inhibits the parasympathetic nervous system.
  • d. Excessive Salivation: This symptom is characteristic of cholinergic poisoning, where increased acetylcholine leads to salivation. Datura results in dry mouth (xerostomia) and decreased salivation, which is typical for anticholinergic agents.

Key Takeaways:

  • Datura Seeds: Contain tropane alkaloids that lead to anticholinergic toxicity.
  • Clinical Features: Include muttering delirium, pin rolling movements, hallucinations, tachycardia, and mydriasis.
  • Management: Primarily supportive care, with physostigmine as an antidote in severe cases to reverse anticholinergic effects.

choices.text: Disseminated viral keratitis with satellite lesions
Has no association with the systemic state of the patient
It can be cultured in chocolate agar
Presence of septate hyphae can be seen in KOH mount

questions.text: A 39 years old lady presented with complaints of redness, watering and decreased vision. Patient has a history of trauma by the cow's tail while collecting milk. What is the peculiarity of the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows Fungal or Mycotic corneal ulcer(PEARLS)

  • Typical history of trauma by vegetative matter is present
  • Indolent course
  • Symptoms- watering, redness, foreign body sensation and decrease in vision
  • Signs- Feathery margins of ulcer, satellite lesions, large hypopyon, can be blood tinged, gritty texture
  • Hypopyon is "not sterile"
  • Investigations- check for diabetic profile, scraping and KOH mount, Calcoflour white stain, sabouraud dextrose agar culture.
  • The ulcer maybe refractory to treatment if patient is immunocompromised
  • Treatment: oral, topical, intralesional and intracameral antifungals. Worse cases may need therapeutic keratoplasty

Fungal (Mycotic) Corneal Ulcer :

Typical Presentation:

  • History of trauma with vegetative matter (e.g., plant material, animal contact).
  • Indolent course with gradual worsening symptoms.

Symptoms:

  • Watering, redness, foreign body sensation, and decreased vision.

Signs:

  • Feathery margins of ulcer, satellite lesions, and a gritty texture.
  • Hypopyon (pus in the anterior chamber) is usually present and non-sterile, often large and sometimes blood-tinged.

Investigations:

  • KOH mount for septate hyphae, Calcofluor white stain for fluorescence, and Sabouraud dextrose agar for fungal culture.
  • Diabetic profile check due to association with immunocompromised states.
  • Giemsa stain: for bacteria and intracytoplasmic inclusions (Chlamydia), not fungi.

Management:

  • Antifungals: Topical (natamycin, voriconazole), oral, intralesional, and intracameral if severe.
  • Surgical intervention: Therapeutic keratoplasty may be necessary in resistant cases.

Why Not Other Options?

  • A. Disseminated viral keratitis: Viral keratitis shows a dendritic or geographic ulcer pattern, not feathery margins.
  • B. No association with the systemic state: Fungal keratitis is more severe in immunocompromised states.
  • C. Chocolate agar culture: Chocolate agar is primarily for bacteria like Neisseria and Haemophilus, not fungi.

Key Takeaways:

  • Fungal Keratitis: Common after vegetative trauma, presents with feathery ulcer margins and satellite lesions.
  • Diagnosis: KOH mount (septate hyphae) and Sabouraud agar culture.
  • Management: Topical and systemic antifungals, possibly surgical intervention in severe cases.

Reference:

  • Kanski, J. (2019). Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 9th Edition, Elsevier, pp. 216-217

choices.text: Inactivated, mouse brain derived vaccine to animals and human
Tick control with acaricides in live stock farms
Personal protective measures in endemic areas

questions.text: What is most appropriate and effective means for prevention and control of CCHF:
questions.solution:
• Inactivated, mouse brain-derived vaccine to animals and humans: Incorrect. While research is ongoing, the inactivated, mouse-brain-derived vaccine is not widely available or considered the most effective control method.
  • Tick control with acaricides in livestock farms: Incorrect. Tick control can help reduce transmission in animals, but it does not comprehensively address human prevention, as CCHF also spreads via human-to-human contact and direct exposure to infected bodily fluids.
  • Personal protective measures in endemic areas: Correct. The most effective method for preventing CCHF is the use of personal protective equipment (PPE), such as gloves, masks, gowns, and eye protection, especially when handling livestock, patients, or deceased individuals in endemic regions.
  • Chemoprophylaxis to persons with suspected exposure: Incorrect. There is no established chemoprophylaxis for CCHF, and prevention primarily focuses on personal protective measures rather than medication.

Why Not Others:

  • A. While vaccines are being studied, the mouse-brain-derived vaccine is not a standard or widely recommended method of prevention.
  • B. Tick control helps prevent CCHF transmission from animals, but does not address human-to-human transmission effectively.
  • D. There is no proven chemoprophylaxis for CCHF, so prevention relies on PPE and good hygiene practices.

Key Takeaways:

  • The most effective prevention for CCHF is the use of personal protective measures (PPE) in endemic areas.
  • Tick control and vaccines play a role in controlling animal-to-human transmission but do not address human-to-human spread directly.
  • Chemoprophylaxis is not a recommended preventive approach for CCHF.

questions.text: 35 years old male presents with nephrotic range proteinuria. On evaluation antibody against phospholipase A2 is present. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Idiopathic Membranous Glomerulonephritis (MGN) is characterized by:
    • Nephrotic syndrome with significant proteinuria.
    • The presence of antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R), which occurs in approximately 70% of idiopathic cases.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Accounts for about 25% of nephrotic syndrome cases in adults.
    • Peak incidence occurs between 30 and 50 years, with a male-to-female ratio of 2:1.
  • Pathology:
    • Renal biopsy typically shows:
      • Uniform thickening of the basement membrane along peripheral capillary loops.
      • Immunofluorescence reveals granular deposits of IgG and C3.
      • Electron microscopy displays electron-dense subepithelial deposits.
  • Differentiation:
    • Subendothelial deposits or tubuloreticular inclusions indicate membranous lupus nephritis.
    • The presence of autoantibodies to thrombospondin type-1 domain-containing 7A (THSD7A) is noted in 3-10% of cases.
  • Prognosis:
    • Factors such as male gender, older age, hypertension, and persistent nephrotic-range proteinuria are associated with a poorer prognosis.
    • MGN has a higher incidence of thrombotic complications like renal vein thrombosis, prompting consideration for prophylactic anticoagulation in patients with hypoalbuminemia.

Why Not Others:

  • Option B: Secondary membranous Glomerulonephritis - This involves other underlying conditions, which is not indicated here.
  • Option C: SLE associated membranous GN - Would show additional features of systemic lupus erythematosus, which are not present in this case.
  • Option D: Drug-induced Membranous Glomerulonephritis - Requires a known drug history, which is absent here.

Key Takeaways:

  • Idiopathic Membranous Glomerulonephritis is confirmed with the presence of PLA2R antibodies and significant nephrotic range proteinuria.
  • Pathological features include thickened membranes and characteristic subepithelial deposits, crucial for diagnosis and differentiation from other forms.

Type: Must Know

questions.text: Which hormonal contraceptive method can reduce the risk of developing ovarian cancer?
questions.solution:
Combined oral contraceptives (COCs), which contain both estrogen and progestin, have been shown to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer.

This protective effect is thought to be due to the suppression of ovulation, reducing the number of ovulatory cycles and potentially limiting the risk of ovarian epithelial cancer.

The longer a woman uses COCs, the greater the protective effect, and this risk reduction can persist for several years after discontinuation.

Why the other options are less likely:

  • Progestin-only pill: While progestin-only methods are effective for contraception, there is less evidence to support the same level of ovarian cancer risk reduction as combined oral contraceptives.
  • LNG Intrauterine system (IUS): The LNG-IUS releases a small amount of progestin, but there is limited evidence to show that it significantly reduces the risk of ovarian cancer. It primarily provides protection against endometrial cancer and has local effects on the uterus.
  • DMPA Injection: Depo-Provera (medroxyprogesterone acetate) is a progestin-only injectable contraceptive. Although it is effective in preventing pregnancy, there is insufficient evidence to suggest it provides the same protective effect against ovarian cancer as combined oral contraceptives.

Key takeaway:

Combined oral contraceptives are the most effective hormonal contraceptive method for reducing the risk of ovarian cancer.

Topic: Non-contraceptive benefits of hormonal contraception

Type: Must know

PYQ NEET INICET

Reference: Speroff's Clinical Gynaecologic Endocrinology & Infertility 9th edition, Chapter 22 Hormonal Contraception, Page no. 2207

choices.text: Sinus rhythm with complete (third-degree) AV block

questions.text: An 85-year-old male, who is asymptomatic and not on any cardiac medications, undergoes an ECG. The ECG reveals a slow ventricular rate of approximately 32 beats per minute, with non-conducted sinus P waves alternating with conducted P waves. The conducted PR intervals are constant at approximately 200 ms. What is the most likely rhythm diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Sinus Rhythm with 2:1 AV Block: The ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm with P waves at a rate of about 64 beats per minute, with every alternate P wave not conducted to the ventricles, resulting in a ventricular rate of about 32 beats per minute. The constant PR interval for the conducted P waves (about 200 ms) suggests 2:1 AV block. Since there is no progressive prolongation of the PR interval, this is a 2:1 AV block rather than a Wenckebach pattern.
  • Key Findings:
    • Ventricular Rate: Approximately 32/min.
    • P Wave Rate: Approximately 64/min.
    • 2:1 AV Conduction: Alternating conducted and non-conducted P waves with constant PR intervals on conducted beats.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A (Atrial tachycardia with AV block): This option would require a faster atrial rate than seen here. Atrial tachycardia typically exceeds 100 beats per minute.
  • Option c (Sinus rhythm with complete AV block): Complete (third-degree) AV block would show a total dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes, which is not seen here.
  • Option D (Sinus rhythm with 3:2 AV Wenckebach): In 3:2 Wenckebach, we would expect a group of three P waves where the third is blocked after progressive PR prolongation, which is not the case here.

Key Takeaways:

  • 2:1 AV Block: Characterized by alternate conduction and non-conduction of P waves with a regular sinus rhythm.
  • PR Interval: A constant PR interval on conducted beats suggests a fixed AV block rather than a progressive Wenckebach pattern.
  • Pacemaker Indication: Pacemaker placement is indicated if the patient becomes symptomatic or if there is evidence of infranodal (His-Purkinje system) block.

Additional Insights:

  • The site of block in 2:1 AV block can be nodal or infranodal. In this case, the narrow QRS complex and normal PR interval (200 ms) suggests nodal involvement. Further testing, such as autonomic interventions (e.g., exercise, carotid sinus massage), may help localize the block.

Tags:

  • Topic: Cardiology, Cardiac Arrhythmias
  • Difficulty Level: Must Know
  • PYQ: INICET MAY 2024; NEET PG 2024

References:

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, ECG atlas, Nathanson LA, McClennen S, Safran C, Goldberger AL. ECG Wave-Maven: Self-Assessment Program for Students and Clinicians. http://ecg.bidmc.harvard.edu.

questions.text: What is the histopathological hallmark of adenomyosis?
questions.solution:
Adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of ectopic endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium, which is the histopathological hallmark of the disease.

OPTION B: Myometrial (& not endometrial) hyperplasia is a feature of Adenomyosis.

OPTION C: If calcifications are observed within the myometrium, it may prompt consideration of other differential diagnoses, such as fibroids or other uterine pathologies, rather than Adenomyosis; like uterine fibroids, chronic endometritis or endometrial carcinoma.

OPTION D: Presence of whorled pattern of smooth muscle cells (watered silk pattern) is characteristic of leiomyoma.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Hypertrophy of Myometrium

Myometrial Hyperplasia

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and ascites. Doppler ultrasound shows absent flow in the hepatic veins. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Budd-Chiari Syndrome

  • Impaired hepatic venous outflow from hepatic veins to IVC.
  • Key Features: Triad of abdominal pain, ascites, hepatomegaly.
  • Common in young women with hypercoagulable conditions.
  • Complications:
    • Liver congestion
    • portal hypertension
    • ascites, varices
    • cirrhosis
    • liver failure.
  • Diagnosis: Doppler ultrasonography, CT scan, and hematological studies.
    • CT scan demonstrates a large, congested liver or cirrhosis with gross enlargement of the caudate lobe resulting from preservation and hypertrophy of the segment due to direct venous drainage to the IVC.
  • Treatment:
    • Liver transplantation for fulminant failure or cirrhosis;
    • TIPSS, portocaval shunt, or IVC stenting if liver function is normal.
    • Lifelong anticoagulation is often required.

Explanation:

Option A. Portal vein thrombosis: Incorrect. Portal vein thrombosis can cause portal hypertension and ascites, but it does not involve the hepatic veins, which are occluded in Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Option B. Budd-Chiari syndrome: Correct. Budd-Chiari syndrome is caused by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow, leading to hepatomegaly, ascites, and abdominal pain. Doppler ultrasound typically shows absent or reduced flow in the hepatic veins.

Option C. Cirrhosis: Incorrect. Cirrhosis presents with similar symptoms but usually shows diffuse liver fibrosis rather than specific venous obstruction.

Option D. Hepatic artery aneurysm: Incorrect. A hepatic artery aneurysm typically presents with a different clinical picture, such as upper abdominal pain or rupture, and does not cause hepatic venous obstruction.

Key Points:

  • Triad of abdominal pain, ascites, hepatomegaly with gross enlargement of the caudate lobe- Budd chiari syndrome

Topic: Budd-Chiari Syndrome

Difficulty Level: Must Know

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 69, page no- 1208

questions.text: A 50 year old woman presents with a groin mass below the inguinal ligament that becomes more prominent with standing. You suspect a femoral hernia. Which structure forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal?
questions.solution:
Femoral Canal

  • Location: The femoral canal lies medial to the femoral vein within the femoral sheath.
  • Contents: The canal contains lymphatic vessels, a lymph node (Cloquet's node), and loose connective tissue.
  • Function: It allows the femoral vein to expand and provides a pathway for lymphatic drainage from the lower limb.
  • Boundaries:
    • Anterior: Inguinal ligament
    • Posterior: Pectineal ligament
    • Medial: Lacunar ligament
    • Lateral: Femoral vein

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Femoral vein: Incorrect. The femoral vein is located lateral to the femoral canal.

Option B. Inguinal ligament: Incorrect. The inguinal ligament forms the superior boundary of the femoral canal.

Option C. Lacunar ligament: Correct. The lacunar ligament forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal.

Option D. Pectineal ligament: Incorrect. The pectineal ligament forms the posterior boundary of the femoral canal.

Key points :

The femoral canal is the site of femoral hernias, more common in women and prone to incarceration due to its narrow structure.

Tags:

Topic: Femoral Canal Anatomy

Difficulty Level: Moderate; Must know

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with a 15-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with:

1. Progressive azotemia
2. Proteinuria (3.8 g/day)
3. Hypertension

Kidney biopsy shows:
1. Nodular glomerulosclerosis with laminated fibrin caps
2. Mesangial matrix expansion
3. Tubular atrophy

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A. The patient's long-standing diabetes, progressive azotemia, proteinuria, and characteristic kidney biopsy findings (nodular glomerulosclerosis with laminated fibrin caps, mesangial matrix expansion, and tubular atrophy) are diagnostic of diabetic nephropathy, specifically Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease.

B. Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is a kidney disorder characterized by:

  • Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)
  • Proliferation of mesangial cells and matrix
  • Deposition of immune complexes and complement factors in the GBM

C. Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is a kidney disease characterized by:

  • Scarring (sclerosis) of glomeruli, the filtering units of the kidney
  • Focal: Affects some glomeruli, not all
  • Segmental: Affects parts of individual glomeruli

D. IgA Nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease, is a kidney disorder characterized by the deposition of IgA antibodies in the glomeruli, leading to inflammation and damage.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran, 10th edition, page no. 1111.

questions.text: A 7 year old child presents with complain of severe throat pain, fever since 2 days. He also developed trismus since 1 day. On examination of oral cavity left side tonsil was pushed medially. Picture Is given below. The best treatment in this condition is ?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture shown above it is suggestive of peritonsillar abscess. It is also known as Quinsy.

The peritonsillar space lies between capsule of tonsil and superior constrictor muscle. Any abscess in this space is called peritonsillar abscess.

It usually spreads from Tonsils. Mainly caused by mixed aerobic ( Group A beta hemolytic streptococcus) and anaerobic organisms.

Clinical features includes painful swallowing , trismus ,hot potato voice, pain in ear fever, malaise.

Management : incision and drainage is the mainstay of treatment. The incision is given just lateral to where a vertical line drawn from anterior border of anterior pillar meets a horizontal line passing through base of uvula. ( Option B )

Antibiotics mostly beta lactum group along with metronidazole is given to cover aerobes and anaerobes respectively. Although Antibiotics alone is not sufficient. ( Option C )

Tonsillectomy is performed after 6 weeks of episode.

Key Takeaway:

Quinsy Management :

  • Intraoral Incision and Drainage
  • Antibiotics ( Aerobic & Anaerobic )
  • Interval Tonsillectomy

  1. Tonsil & Quinsy
  2. Must know

questions.text: Which method is best suited for antibiotic sensitivity testing?
questions.solution:
Bacterial Culture Techniques

  1. Lawn Culture
    • Purpose: Provides uniform bacterial growth on the surface of an agar plate.
    • Application: Essential for antibiotic sensitivity testing using the disc diffusion method.
  2. Streak Culture
    • Purpose: Used to isolate individual colonies from a mixed culture.
  3. Pour-Plate Culture
    • Purpose: Used for quantitating bacteria in a sample by mixing diluted samples with molten agar.
  4. Stab Culture
    • Purpose: Used for maintaining stock cultures under anaerobic conditions.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Uniform growth for sensitivity testing
  • Used in disc diffusion method

questions.text: 20 years old girl presents with Symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome. which can be reproduced when the patient has both arms in the 90° abduction-external rotation position and asked to open and close the hands slowly over a 3-minute period. This provocative test is called?
questions.solution:
The test described in the question is a provocative test for thoracic outlet syndrome called Roos test (Extended arm stress test).

Provocative tests for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome:

Option A : Adson test (Scalene Manoeuvre):

The examiner locates the radial pulse and the patient is asked

  • to Turn the head towards the affected side
  • Extend the neck
  • Take deep breath and hold

Inference: A positive test is indicated by a disappearance of the pulse.

Option B:Halsted Test (Costoclavicular Manoeuvre):

The examiner locates the radial pulse and draws the patient's shoulder down and back as the patient lifts their chest in an exaggerated "attention' posture.

Inference: A positive test is indicated by an absence of a pulse.

Option C: Wright Test (Hyperabduction Manoeuvre)

Patients arm is hyper abducted to 180 and externally rotated

Inference: loss of radial pulse suggests compression

Option D: Roos test or EAST Test (Extended Arm Stress Test):

Method: The patient has both arms in the 90" abduction-external rotation position, The patient is to open and close the hands slowly over a 3-minute period.

Inference: Reproduction of symptoms suggests compression.

TAGS:

TOPIC :CLINICAL TEST FOR THORACIC OUTLET OBSTRUCTION

Difficulty : good to know

choices.text: Transformation involves the transfer of a plasmid from one bacterium to another through a pilus.
Transformation is the process where free DNA from one bacterium is taken up by another bacterium, as demonstrated by Griffith's experiment with pneumococcus.
Transformation occurs when bacteriophages transfer DNA between bacteria.
Transformation is the process of injecting purified DNA into the nucleus of a bacterial cell.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the process of bacterial transformation?
questions.solution:
• Option A describes conjugation, not transformation. Conjugation involves the transfer of plasmids through a sex pilus.
  • Option B accurately describes transformation, where free DNA from one bacterium is incorporated into another bacterium. Griffith's experiment with pneumococcus demonstrated this by showing how non-capsulated bacteria could gain the ability to produce a capsule from dead, capsulated bacteria.
  • Option C describes transduction, where bacteriophages mediate DNA transfer between bacteria.
  • Option D describes transfection, a process where purified DNA is introduced into a bacterial cell, but this is not the same as transformation.

KEY TAKE AWAY: Transformation is a process where bacteria take up free DNA from their environment and incorporate it into their genome, as demonstrated by Griffith's experiment.

Tags: inicet nov 2022

Tags: Clinical Question, Moderate

Reference: Sastry, A. S., & Bhat, S. K. (2022). Review of Microbiology & Immunology (With DVD) (4th ed.). Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers. Chapter1.2: , Page NO.42.

choices.text: Immediate referral for colposcopy and biopsy

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents for her routine gynecological exam. She is asymptomatic. A Pap smear reveals high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL). What is the next appropriate step in her management?
questions.solution:
HSIL on Pap smear indicates a significant risk of cervical cancer or its precursors. Immediate for colposcopy and biopsy is necessary to further evaluate the lesion and determine the extent of dysplasia or malignancy.

Explanation:

OPTION A: HSIL is a significant abnormality that indicates a high risk of cervical precancer or cancer. Repeating the Pap smear without further evaluation is not appropriate as it delays necessary diagnostic intervention.

OPTION B: OPTION C: Observation and follow-up are not recommended for HSIL due to the increased risk of progression to cervical cancer. Immediate diagnostic evaluation is necessary.

OPTION D: HPV vaccination can prevent future infections with HPV types that cause cervical cancer, it does not address existing HSIL. The immediate priority is to evaluate and manage the current lesion.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL) refer to moderate to severe changes in the cells of the cervix.
  • The risk that HSIL abnormalities signify precancerous changes is as high as 53 percent, and the risk of cervical cancer is as high as 7 percent.
  • For most people with HSIL on a Pap test, follow-up involves a colposcopy.
  • In some cases, the clinician will advise immediate (expedited) treatment at the same visit as the colposcopy with a "loop electrosurgical excision procedure" (also called a LEEP or large loop excision of the transformation zone [LLETZ]).

Type: Must know

Topic: Management of HSIL

PYQ NEET INICET

Reference: ASCCP Guidelines on Pap Smear Cytology

questions.text: Which of the following is the most dreaded complication of late diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Congenital hypothyroidism (CH) is a condition present at birth where the thyroid gland fails to produce adequate thyroid hormones, crucial for growth, metabolism, and brain development in infants.

Clinical Features

  1. Newborn Features (often subtle):
    • Prolonged jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
    • Poor feeding
    • Lethargy or decreased activity
    • Hypotonia (reduced muscle tone or "floppiness")
    • Large fontanelles (soft spots on the head, especially the posterior fontanelle)
    • Constipation
  2. Physical Signs:
    • Puffy face with a broad nose
    • Macroglossia (enlarged tongue)
    • Cold, mottled skin
    • Umbilical hernia
    • Coarse or dry skin and hair
    • Enlarged abdomen
    • Hoarse cry
  3. Growth and Developmental Features (if untreated):
    • Growth retardation
    • Delayed skeletal maturation
    • Intellectual disability (mental retardation)
    • Developmental delays in motor skills, cognition, and language

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Late diagnosis and delayed treatment can lead to impaired neurocognitive development and growth.

The risk of neurocognitive complications is significantly reduced if early diagnosis and treatment is started within first two weeks of life.

Tags:

Topic: THYROID DISORDERS

Difficulty level: MUST KNOW

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 2915

choices.text: Pain and tenderness in sacro-iliac region
Rugger jersey spine on x ray

questions.text: All are true regarding ankylosing spondylitis except-
questions.solution:
Ankylosing Spondylitis and HLA-B27 Association

A strong association has been identified between the genetic marker HLA-B27 and ankylosing spondylitis.

Key Features and Progression:

  • (Option C) - Initial Joint Involvement: The sacroiliac joints are typically the first to be affected, followed by the spine, progressing upward from the lumbar region.
  • (Option A) - Ocular Involvement: Approximately 25% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis experience at least one episode of acute iritis.

Radiological Findings (X-ray of the Lumbar Spine):

  • Squaring of Vertebrae: Loss of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body due to calcification of the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Loss of Lumbar Lordosis: Flattening of the natural curve in the lumbar region.
  • Bridging Osteophytes (Syndesmophytes): Bony outgrowths connecting adjacent vertebrae.
  • (Option B) - Bamboo Spine Appearance: The spine takes on a rigid, bamboo-like appearance due to extensive syndesmophyte formation and vertebral fusion leading to stiffness.
  • There is also evidence of enthesopathy - calcification at the attachment of the muscles, tendons and ligaments, particularly around the pelvis and around the heel.

Ankylosing spondylitis Radiological Finding :

Option A, B & C : Chances of developing acute iritis, Stiff spine & Pain and tenderness in sacro-iliac region all three features seen in AS.

Option D : Rugger jersey spine is seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Key Takeaway -

Spine Appearance in various diseases :

  • Bamboo spine - Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Rugger Jersey spine - Hyperparathyroidism
  • Picture frame vertebra - paget's disease.

Tags :

Joint disorders and joint reconstruction

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman visits a psychiatrist after experiencing severe mood swings and intense fear of abandonment. She describes her relationships as chaotic and often finds herself in crises. She has a history of self-harming behaviors and feels empty when not in a relationship. Her emotions fluctuate dramatically, and she struggles with her self-image.
Which personality disorder best fits her description?
questions.solution:
Key Features (Mnemonic: IMPULSIVE)

  1. Instability in interpersonal relationships: Intense and unstable relationships, alternating between idealization and devaluation.
  2. Mood instability: Marked reactivity of mood (e.g., intense episodes of sadness, irritability, or anxiety).
  3. Poor self-image: Chronic feelings of emptiness or unstable self-identity.
  4. Unsuitable anger: Inappropriate, intense anger or difficulty controlling it.
  5. Leaving relationships in fear: Fear of abandonment, leading to frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined separation.
  6. Self-harm or suicidal behavior: Frequent self-injurious behavior or threats of suicide.
  7. Impulsivity: Risky behaviors like substance abuse, reckless driving, or binge eating.
  8. Vulnerable to stress: Paranoia or severe dissociation during stress.
  9. Emotional instability: Rapid shifts in emotional states.

Option A: Borderline Personality Disorder True. The symptoms described, including mood instability, fear of abandonment, self-harming behaviors, and identity issues, are hallmark traits of borderline personality disorder.

Option B: Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder False. This disorder is characterized by perfectionism and rigidity rather than emotional instability or fear of abandonment.

Option C: Avoidant Personality Disorder False. Although she has issues with relationships, avoidant personality disorder primarily involves sensitivity to rejection and a desire for social connection, which is not highlighted in this scenario.

Option D: Histrionic Personality Disorder False. While this disorder involves emotionality and attention-seeking behavior, the woman's primary struggles with identity and abandonment are more indicative of borderline personality disorder.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Borderline Personality Disorder is a psychiatric condition characterized by pervasive instability in moods, behavior, self-image, and interpersonal relationships. It often leads to significant emotional distress and difficulty in functioning.

Tags:

  • Topic: Personality disorders
  • Difficulty Level: Must know
  • PYQ: INICET MAY 2024

References: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 19, Pages 1778

questions.text: What is the unit of measurement in CT scan?
questions.solution:
The Hounsfield unit (HU) is a measurement used in computed tomography (CT) to quantify radiodensity. It is named after Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, who contributed to the development of CT scanning.

The Hounsfield scale is standardized with:

  • Air: -1000 HU
  • Water: 0 HU
  • Fat: around -100 to -50 HU
  • Muscle: approximately +40 to +60 HU
  • Bone: ranges from +300 to +3000 HU, depending on the type of bone.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The Hounsfield unit (HU) is a measurement used in computed tomography (CT) to quantify radiodensity

Reference: Christensen's Physics of Diagnostic Radiology, fourth edition, page no: 308

questions.text: PERT technique is used in following:
questions.solution:
• The Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) is used for network analysis, particularly in project management.
  • It helps in planning, scheduling, and monitoring projects by breaking down tasks and estimating the time required for completion, identifying the critical path that determines the project's minimum completion time.
  • PERT is ideal for projects with uncertain task durations, improving coordination and communication across different levels involved in the project.

Types of Network Techniques:

  • PERT: Utilizes an arrow diagram to outline the logical sequence of events, helping estimate time and monitor progress.
  • Critical Path Method (CPM): Focuses on determining the longest path in the network, known as the critical path, where any delay affects the entire project timeline.

Why Not Other Options:

  • B. Cost-effective analysis: PERT is primarily about time estimation and task scheduling, not cost assessment.
  • C. Input-output analysis: This refers to economic modelling of inputs and outputs, unrelated to project scheduling.
  • D. System analysis: Focuses on evaluating and improving entire systems, while PERT is specifically for task sequencing and time estimation in projects.

Key Takeaways:

  • PERT is a tool for network analysis, focusing on project planning and scheduling, identifying critical tasks that dictate the project timeline.

Tags: fmge June 2023

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-23, Page no: 1000-1001.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to medicine OPD for an evaluation of feeling sleepiness. He reports daytime sleepiness for the past one month that interferes with his ability to work. He has a history of chronic kidney disease with a serum creatinine level of 3.2mg/dl. He has refractory hypertension for which he takes four medications. Which of the following may be the cause of his somnolence?
questions.solution:
• Somnolence is a common adverse effect of the anti-hypertensive drug clonidine.
  • This drug is an alpha-2 agonist which decreases norepinephrine release. In the periphery, this causes a fall in adrenergic tone which lowers blood pressure.
  • Excessive sleepiness is a common complaint of patients taking this drug.
  • Clonidine is sometimes used as a therapy for insomnia in children

Adverse effects of clonidine

  • Sedation, mental depression, disturbed sleep; dryness of mouth, nose and eyes, constipation
  • Impotence, salt and water retention, bradycardia.
  • Postural hypotension
  • On sudden withdrawal -- > Alarming rise in BP, in excess of pretreatment level, with tachycardia, restlessness, anxiety, sweating, headache, nausea and vomiting

Option A: Uremia may lead to confusion and fatigue

Option B: Hydralazine is a direct vasodilator, Adverse effects include reflex tachycardia and drug-induced lupus. It is not associated with somnolence.

Option D: Fenoldopam is an intravenous drug used in hypertensive urgency and emergency. It is a dopamine agonist and, like many dopamine agonists, it is stimulatory, It can cause anxiety and insomnia.

Key takeaway:

  • Excessive sleepiness is a common complaint of patients taking this drug along with Sedation, mental depression, disturbed sleep.

Tags:

  • Clonidine
  • Good to know
  • Neet 2023

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no: 611

questions.text: Which organ is primarily affected by GIVEN PARASITIC infection?
questions.solution:
• Liver: Not primarily affected by P.westermani; other parasites tend to target the liver more often.
  • Lungs: This is the primary site of infection for P.westermani, causing paragonimiasis and leading to significant respiratory symptoms like chronic cough and hemoptysis.
  • Kidneys: The kidneys do not serve as a major site for P.westermani infection; it is mainly a respiratory parasite.
  • Heart: This organ is also unaffected by P.westermani; the focus of infection remains in the lungs.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Liver: Infections related to the liver are typically caused by different parasites, not P.westermani.
  • B) Lungs: Correct choice; P.westermani is known for primarily affecting the lungs.
  • C) Kidneys: No primary association with P.westermani; it does not infect the kidneys.
  • D) Heart: This organ is not impacted by P.westermani; the parasite's activity is limited to the respiratory tract.

Key Takeaway:

  • Paragonimus westermani predominantly affects the lungs, resulting in symptoms similar to tuberculosis. Early detection and treatment are essential to manage the infection effectively.
