Tag Line: Moderate

REFERENCE: By P. westermani., CDC.

questions.text: Which swab material is recommended for collecting specimens to avoid inhibition of bacterial growth, especially for anaerobic cultures?
questions.solution:
• Calcium Alginate Swab (Option C): Calcium alginate swabs are recommended for anaerobic cultures because they do not contain substances that inhibit bacterial growth. Calcium alginate is chemically inert and does not interfere with bacterial metabolism or growth, making it ideal for preserving the integrity of the specimen during transportation and culture.

Other answers:

  • Cotton Swab (Option A): Cotton swabs are not recommended for anaerobic cultures because cotton can contain fatty acids and other substances that inhibit the growth of certain bacteria, including anaerobes. This inhibition can compromise the results of the culture.
  • Wooden Stick Swab (Option B): Wooden stick swabs are also unsuitable for bacterial cultures, particularly anaerobic ones, because wood can introduce inhibitors and cause contamination. Additionally, wooden sticks can absorb and leach out moisture, affecting the specimen.
  • Dacron Swab (Option D): Dacron swabs are generally acceptable for many bacterial cultures, including some anaerobes. However, they are not as specifically recommended as calcium alginate swabs for anaerobic cultures. Dacron swabs are suitable for specimens where the specific inhibition concerns of cotton or wooden swabs are not as significant.

KEY TAKE AWAY: Calcium alginate swabs are preferred for collecting specimens intended for anaerobic cultures because they do not inhibit bacterial growth, ensuring accurate and reliable culture results. This makes them a better choice compared to cotton or wooden stick swabs, which can introduce substances that might interfere with anaerobic bacterial growth.

Tags: neet 2021

Tags: Clinical Question, Moderate

Reference: Sastry, A. S., & Bhat, S. K. (2022). Review of Microbiology & Immunology (With DVD) (4th ed.)chapter -1.3 page no: 36.

choices.text: MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens to CD8+ T cells, while MHC class II molecules present exogenous antigens to CD4+ T cells
MHC class I molecules are found only on professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs), whereas MHC class II molecules are expressed on all nucleated cells
MHC class I molecules present exogenous antigens, whereas MHC class II molecules present endogenous antigens
MHC class I molecules are involved in activating helper T cells, while MHC class II molecules are involved in activating cytotoxic T cells

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes a key difference between MHC class I and MHC class II molecules?
questions.solution:
• A. MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens to CD8+ T cells, while MHC class II molecules present exogenous antigens to CD4+ T cells: This is correct. MHC class I molecules present peptides from intracellular (endogenous) proteins to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, while MHC class II molecules present peptides from extracellular (exogenous) proteins to CD4+ helper T cells.
  • B. MHC class I molecules are found only on professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs), whereas MHC class II molecules are expressed on all nucleated cells: This is incorrect. MHC class I molecules are expressed on all nucleated cells, while MHC class II molecules are restricted to professional APCs (such as dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells).
  • C. MHC class I molecules present exogenous antigens, whereas MHC class II molecules present endogenous antigens: This is incorrect. MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens, while MHC class II molecules present exogenous antigens.
  • D. MHC class I molecules are involved in activating helper T cells, while MHC class II molecules are involved in activating cytotoxic T cells: This is incorrect. MHC class I molecules activate cytotoxic T cells (CD8+), and MHC class II molecules activate helper T cells (CD4+).

Key Takeaway: MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells and are expressed on all nucleated cells, whereas MHC class II molecules present exogenous antigens to CD4+ helper T cells and are primarily expressed on antigen-presenting cells.

Tags: Inicet 2022

Tag line: Hard

Reference: Shastri, A., & Bhatt, S. (2023). Essential Microbiology. Chapter 14, Autoimmunity, PG NO: 170-183.

choices.text: Quantitative data of a group of patients
Qualitative data of a group of patients

questions.text: Histogram is used to describe:
questions.solution:
• Histogram Overview:
    • A histogram is a graphical representation that displays the distribution of quantitative (numerical) data. It uses bars to show the frequency of data points within specified ranges (intervals).
  • Key Points:
    • Quantitative data of a group of patients (Correct Answer):
      • Histograms effectively represent quantitative data, such as measurements like age, weight, or blood pressure.
      • X-axis: Represents ranges of values (bins).
      • Y-axis: Represents the frequency of data points in each range.

Why not others:

  • Qualitative data of a group of patients:
    • Incorrect; qualitative data (e.g., gender, race) is better suited for bar charts or pie charts, which show frequency counts of categories rather than numerical intervals.
  • Data collected on nominal scale:
    • Incorrect; nominal scale data consists of categories without inherent order (e.g., blood type, gender) and does not fit a histogram's numerical nature.
  • Data collected on ordinal scale:
    • Incorrect; while ordinal data has a meaningful order (e.g., pain levels), it is not strictly numerical. Bar charts are more appropriate for representing ordinal data.

Key takeaways:

  • Histograms are designed for displaying the distribution of quantitative data, providing insights into patterns, central tendencies, and variability.
  • Understanding the type of data being analyzed is crucial for selecting the appropriate graphical representation, with histograms being specific to quantitative data only.
  • Effective data visualization is vital for interpreting research findings and communicating results clearly.

Tags: inicet nov 2023

Reference: Mahajan's Methods in Biostatistics for Medical Students and Research Workers, Eighth Edition, chapter-02,Page No: 20-30.

questions.text: In a patient with sudden onset of language loss and right homonymous hemianopia, which arterial territory is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
• Option A (Left middle cerebral artery - MCA) is Correct: The left MCA supplies the language centers of the brain, including Broca's and Wernicke's areas, in the dominant hemisphere (which is typically the left side in most right-handed individuals). Right homonymous hemianopia occurs due to the involvement of the optic radiations in the left hemisphere. A stroke in the left MCA territory can lead to aphasia (language loss) and right-sided visual field defects (homonymous hemianopia).
  • Option B (Right anterior cerebral artery - ACA) is Incorrect: The right ACA supplies the medial portion of the frontal lobes and paracentral lobule, which primarily affects motor and sensory functions in the contralateral lower limb, not language or visual fields.
  • Option C (Left posterior cerebral artery - PCA) is Incorrect: The left PCA supplies the occipital lobe, and a stroke here could cause right homonymous hemianopia, but it would not typically result in language loss, as the PCA does not supply the primary language centers.
  • Option D (Right vertebral artery) is Incorrect: The right vertebral artery supplies parts of the brainstem and cerebellum. Stroke in this territory would more likely present with vertigo, ataxia, or cranial nerve deficits, rather than language loss or visual field defects.

Key Takeaways:

  1. A stroke in the left MCA territory is associated with language deficits (aphasia) and right homonymous hemianopia, due to involvement of the dominant hemisphere and optic radiations.
  2. The PCA territory stroke may cause visual field defects but would not typically lead to aphasia unless it involves adjacent regions.
  3. Understanding arterial territories is essential for localizing neurological deficits in stroke patients.

Tags:

  • Topic: Neurology (Stroke Syndromes)
  • Difficulty Level: Good to Know
  • PYQ Reference: NEET PG 2022; Inicet Nov 2021; nov 2022

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 426, Page no: 3326

choices.text: The patient exhibits a pattern of recurrent binge-eating episodes without any compensatory behaviors
The patient has a distorted body image and engages in behaviors to prevent weight gain despite being underweight
The patient experiences regular episodes of eating large quantities of food followed by self-induced vomiting
The patient eats excessively in response to emotional distress but does not engage in compensatory behaviors

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes a key diagnostic feature of Anorexia Nervosa?
questions.solution:
Anorexia Nervosa

  • Diagnostic Criteria:
    • DSM-5 and ICD-10 recognize Anorexia Nervosa as a distinct disorder.
    • Key symptoms include:
      • Food restriction leading to abnormally low weight.
      • Intense fear of gaining weight.
      • Distorted body image.
      • Self-evaluation based primarily on thinness.
      • Loss of appetite or engagement in weight-loss behaviors.
    • Types:
      • Restricting Type: Primarily dieting, fasting, and excessive exercise for the last 3 months.
      • Binge-Eating/Purging Type: Involves binging and purging behaviors.
    • Severity Specifiers:
      • Severity is measured by BMI levels.
      • Partial and full remission definitions.
    • Medical Complications:
      • Vital signs: Bradycardia, hypotension, hypothermia.
      • General: Muscle atrophy, loss of body fat.
      • CNS: Brain atrophy, seizures.
      • Cardiovascular: Edema, decreased cardiac output.
      • Renal: Prerenal azotemia.
      • Gastrointestinal: Delayed gastric emptying.
      • Metabolic: Hypercholesterolemia, hypoglycemia.
      • Endocrine: Hormonal imbalances.

Option A: The patient exhibits a pattern of recurrent binge-eating episodes without any compensatory behaviors.

This statement describes Binge-Eating Disorder, not Anorexia Nervosa. Anorexia Nervosa involves significant weight loss due to food restriction, a fear of gaining weight, and a distorted body image.

Option B: The patient has a distorted body image and engages in behaviors to prevent weight gain despite being underweight.

This is the correct answer. A key diagnostic feature of Anorexia Nervosa is the individual's distorted perception of body weight or shape and their engagement in restrictive behaviors that lead to significant weight loss.

Option C: The patient experiences regular episodes of eating large quantities of food followed by self-induced vomiting.

This statement describes Bulimia Nervosa, where individuals engage in binge-eating followed by compensatory behaviors like vomiting. Anorexia Nervosa does not primarily involve these binge-purge cycles.

Option D: The patient eats excessively in response to emotional distress but does not engage in compensatory behaviors.

This describes Binge-Eating Disorder, characterized by binge-eating without subsequent purging or compensatory behaviors. Anorexia Nervosa is characterized by severe restriction of food intake and extreme weight loss.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: A key diagnostic feature of Anorexia Nervosa is the individual's distorted perception of body weight or shape and their engagement in restrictive behaviors that lead to significant weight loss.

Tags:

  • Topic: Binge eating, Anorexia Nervosa
  • Difficulty Level: Must know
  • PYQ: NEET PG 2022;

References: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 13, Page no: 1499.

questions.text: In case of oral squamous cell carcinoma, the degree of histologic differentiation is determined by?
questions.solution:
The degree of keratinization is related to the histologic differentiation of a tumor, particularly in squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs), as follows:

  • Well-differentiated SCCs: High degree of keratinization, with prominent keratin pearls and intercellular bridges.
  • Moderately differentiated SCCs: Moderate degree of keratinization, with some keratin pearls and intercellular bridges.
  • Poorly differentiated SCCs: Low degree of keratinization, with few or no keratin pearls and intercellular bridges.

KERATINISATION:

  • Keratinization is a key feature of squamous cell differentiation, and its degree serves as an indicator of the tumor's resemblance to normal squamous epithelium.
  • Tumors with high keratinization are more differentiated, meaning they retain more of the characteristics of normal cells, whereas those with low keratinization are less differentiated, meaning they have lost more of their normal cellular features.

Option B: The growth rate of a tumor is not directly related to its degree of histologic differentiation for several reasons:

  • Tumor heterogeneity: Tumors are composed of diverse cell populations, each with varying growth rates and differentiation levels.
  • Genetic mutations: Specific genetic mutations can drive rapid growth regardless of differentiation status.
  • Microenvironmental factors: The tumor microenvironment, including blood supply, immune response, and stromal interactions, influences growth rates.
  • Angiogenesis: Tumors can develop new blood vessels to support growth, regardless of differentiation.
  • Cancer stem cells: A small subpopulation of cancer stem cells can drive tumor growth and recurrence, independent of differentiation.
  • Epigenetic changes: Epigenetic modifications can affect gene expression, leading to increased growth rates without altering differentiation.

Option C: Mitotic rate, which refers to the frequency of cell divisions, is not directly related to the degree of histologic differentiation of a tumor for several reasons:

  • Mitotic rate is a measure of proliferation, not differentiation: Mitosis measures how quickly cells divide, whereas differentiation refers to the degree of cellular specialization.
  • Differentiated cells can still proliferate rapidly: Well-differentiated tumor cells can exhibit high mitotic rates, especially in certain tumor types like lymphomas.
  • Undifferentiated cells can proliferate slowly: Poorly differentiated or anaplastic tumor cells may exhibit low mitotic rates due to various factors like cellular stress or microenvironmental limitations.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 737.

choices.text: Obtain a CT scan of the orbit

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a history of Graves' disease presents for follow-up evaluation. On examination, the patient demonstrates noticeable proptosis in her right eye. The exophthalmometer reveals measurements of 24 mm in the right eye and 20 mm in the left eye. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Obtain a CT scan of the orbit:
    • Given the asymmetric proptosis and the patient's history of Graves' disease, a CT scan is crucial for evaluating potential orbital masses, inflammation, or other complications.

Exophthalmometer

Definition:
An exophthalmometer is a specialized instrument used to measure the degree of proptosis (forward displacement of the eye) in patients. It provides an objective assessment of ocular protrusion, which is essential in diagnosing and monitoring conditions such as thyroid eye disease (Graves' disease), tumors, or inflammatory processes affecting the orbit.

Types of Exophthalmometers

  1. Hertel Exophthalmometer:
    • Most commonly used in clinical practice.
    • Consists of two horizontal arms with a ruler and a fixed reference point.
    • The patient is positioned with their head in a neutral position, and measurements are taken from the lateral canthus to the corneal apex.
  2. La Salle Exophthalmometer:
    • A less commonly used type, featuring a simple design.
    • Measures proptosis in a similar manner but is less prevalent in modern practice.
  3. Digital Exophthalmometer:
    • Utilizes electronic sensors for precise measurements.
    • Displays the results digitally and can store data for future reference.

Indications for Use

  • Thyroid Eye Disease: To assess the degree of proptosis and monitor progression or response to treatment.
  • Orbital Tumors: To evaluate changes in eye position due to mass effects.
  • Inflammatory Conditions: Such as orbital cellulitis or inflammatory pseudotumor.
  • Trauma: To assess any displacement of the eye following orbital injuries.

Procedure

  1. Patient Positioning: The patient is seated comfortably with their head in a neutral position, looking straight ahead.
  2. Alignment: The exophthalmometer is placed at the lateral canthus of the eye being measured, ensuring it is level with the horizontal plane.
  3. Measurement: The distance from the lateral canthus to the corneal apex is recorded. This measurement is usually compared to the fellow eye to assess for asymmetry.
  4. Recording Results: The measurement is noted in millimeters, typically averaging between 12-20 mm for normal adults, with slight variations depending on ethnicity and individual anatomy.

Interpretation of Results

  • Normal Proptosis: Typically ranges from 12-20 mm.
  • Mild Proptosis: 21-23 mm, may suggest early thyroid eye disease or other orbital pathology.
  • Moderate Proptosis: 24-26 mm, often indicative of more significant disease activity or presence of a mass.
  • Severe Proptosis: >27 mm, usually associated with advanced thyroid eye disease, large orbital tumors, or acute inflammatory processes.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A) Initiate high-dose corticosteroids:
    • Reserved for acute inflammation; imaging should be prioritized to assess for mass effect or complications first.
  • B) Refer for orbital decompression surgery:
    • Typically considered only for severe cases leading to vision loss or significant complications; imaging is needed before referral.
  • D) Start topical lubricants and monitor:
    • While helpful for managing dry eye symptoms, this approach does not address the underlying cause, especially with the significant asymmetry in measurements.

Key Takeaways:

  • Exophthalmometer is crucial for assessing proptosis, especially in conditions like Graves' disease. The next step in management should be imaging (CT scan) to evaluate for potential complications and guide further treatment.

exophthalmometer

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Saunders Elsevier; 2015. pg no: 215-217.

choices.text: Phase 0 occurs due to influx of Ca2+
Phase 1 occurs due to influx of Na+
Phase 2 occurs due to entry of Ca-+ channel via T-type Ca2-+ channel
Phase 3 occurs due to efflux of K+

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding ventricular muscle action potential shown below:
questions.solution:
• Phase 0 (Depolarization):
    This phase occurs due to the influx of Na⁺, not Ca²⁺. Rapid depolarization is primarily driven by sodium channels opening.
  • Phase 1 (Early Repolarization):
    Phase 1 is characterized by efflux of K⁺ from the myocyte via transient potassium channels, leading to a brief drop in membrane potential.
  • Phase 2 (Plateau):
    Phase 2 is marked by the entry of Ca²⁺ through L-type Ca²⁺ channels, not T-type channels, contributing to the plateau of the action potential.
  • Phase 3 (Late Repolarization):
    This phase involves the efflux of K⁺ through delayed rectifier potassium channels, resulting in repolarization of the membrane.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: Phase 0 is primarily due to the influx of Na⁺.
  • B: Phase 1 is due to K⁺ efflux, not Na⁺ influx.
  • C: False. Phase 2 involves L-type Ca²⁺ channels, not T-type.

Key Takeaways:

Ventricular muscle action potential consists of distinct phases, with Phase 3 correctly identified as the phase associated with efflux of K⁺, leading to repolarization. Understanding these phases is essential for grasping cardiac electrophysiology and the mechanics of heart function.

Tags: Inicet nov 2020

Topic: Cardiac electrophysiology

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology 26th Edition Page no: 1183 fig 29-2

questions.text:
Choose whether sentences are T-True or F-false
1. Ventricular filling is 70% passive filling
2. Ventricular filling is fast in phase of diastasis
3. 2.Ventricular filling is reduced by 20% in atrial fibrillation
questions.solution:
Mechanics of Filling:

  • Passive Filling: 70% of ventricular filling occurs passively during diastole.
  • Active Filling: 30% of filling occurs actively during atrial systole.

Diastasis Phase:

  • Slow Filling: Ventricular filling is slow during the diastasis phase, which is the period between rapid filling and atrial contraction.

Atrial Fibrillation Impact:

  • Reduction in Filling: Ventricular filling is reduced by 20% in cases of atrial fibrillation due to the loss of effective atrial contraction.

D: TFT is correct for above three statements. It is correct answer.

A, B and C are incorrect

Key takeaways: Ventricular filling is 70% passive, slow during diastasis, and reduced by about 20% in atrial fibrillation.

Tags: Fmge jan 2023

Tag: Cardiac output

Reference: Ganong's Review of medical Physiology , 26th Edition, Chapter 30, page no: 1220, 1221

questions.text: What is a characteristic marker combination for a supercarrier of Hepatitis B?
questions.solution:
• HBsAg Positive: Indicates an ongoing Hepatitis B infection, signifying the presence of the virus.
  • HBeAg Positive: Suggests high viral replication and increased infectivity, which is common in supercarriers.
  • Supercarrier State: Typically exhibits both HBsAg and HBeAg positivity, often with normal liver enzymes, indicating a carrier state with a high viral load but asymptomatic.
  • HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs positive: Suggests a transition or recovery phase from Hepatitis B, not indicative of a supercarrier state.
  • HBsAg negative, Anti-HBs positive: Indicates recovery from infection or vaccination, thus not characteristic of a supercarrier.
  • HBsAg positive, Anti-HBc IgM positive: Points to an acute infection rather than a chronic supercarrier state.

Why Not Others:

  • a)HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs positive: Indicates recovery or transition, not a supercarrier.
  • c)HBsAg negative, Anti-HBs positive: Reflects recovery or vaccination, excluding supercarrier status.
  • d)HBsAg positive, Anti-HBc IgM positive: Indicates acute infection, which is not typical for supercarriers.

Key Takeaway: A supercarrier of Hepatitis B is characterized by HBsAg positive and HBeAg positive, reflecting high viral load and infectivity while often remaining asymptomatic. This combination indicates a chronic infection with significant replication of the virus.

Tags: Neet 2023

CDC Reference: For details on Hepatitis B carrier states, see CDC Hepatitis B Overview.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being educated about the progression of diabetic nephropathy. Arrange the following events in the correct chronological order from first to last in the development of diabetic nephropathy.
A. Onset of microalbuminuria
B. Development of glomerular hyperfiltration and renal hypertrophy
C. Appearance of overt proteinuria (macroalbuminuria)
D. Decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) leading to renal insufficiency
E. Progression to end-stage renal disease (ESRD)
questions.solution:
The progression of diabetic nephropathy in patients with type 2 diabetes typically follows these stages:

  1. Development of Glomerular Hyperfiltration and Renal Hypertrophy (B):
    • Initial Phase: In the early years after the onset of diabetes, patients experience an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and kidney size due to hyperglycemia-induced hemodynamic changes. This stage, known as glomerular hyperfiltration, is often asymptomatic but sets the stage for further kidney damage.
  2. Onset of Microalbuminuria (A):
    • Microalbuminuria Stage: Approximately 5-10 years after diabetes onset, small amounts of albumin start to appear in the urine, detectable as microalbuminuria. This stage is a crucial marker of early nephropathy and represents damage to the glomerular filtration barrier. Microalbuminuria is defined as 30-300 mg/day of albumin in the urine.
  3. Appearance of Overt Proteinuria (Macroalbuminuria) (C):
    • Progression to Macroalbuminuria: Microalbuminuria progresses to macroalbuminuria (also known as overt proteinuria) as kidney damage becomes more pronounced. Macroalbuminuria is defined as >300 mg/day of protein in the urine and indicates significant nephropathy and risk of further kidney function decline.
  4. Decline in GFR Leading to Renal Insufficiency (D):
    • Progressive Renal Dysfunction: Persistent proteinuria eventually leads to a decline in GFR, indicating progressive kidney damage and renal insufficiency. This stage is marked by a gradual reduction in the filtering capacity of the kidneys, resulting in an increase in serum creatinine and worsening kidney function.
  5. Progression to End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) (E):
    • Final Stage: Ultimately, continued decline in kidney function progresses to end-stage renal disease (ESRD), where the kidneys fail to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance. At this stage, renal replacement therapy (dialysis or transplantation) is required to sustain life.

Key Points:

  1. Glomerular Hyperfiltration (B): The earliest stage with increased GFR and kidney hypertrophy due to hyperglycemia-induced hemodynamic changes.
  2. Microalbuminuria (A): The initial sign of diabetic nephropathy with 30-300 mg/day albumin in urine, marking early glomerular damage.
  3. Macroalbuminuria (C): Higher levels of protein in urine (>300 mg/day), indicating significant progression of nephropathy.
  4. Decline in GFR (D): The gradual reduction in kidney filtering capacity leading to renal insufficiency and increased serum creatinine.
  5. End-Stage Renal Disease (E): Final stage where renal replacement therapy (dialysis or transplant) is necessary due to kidney failure.

Additional Notes:

  • Early Detection: Regular screening for microalbuminuria in diabetic patients is critical for early intervention.
  • Management Strategies: Tight glycemic control, blood pressure management (preferably with ACE inhibitors or ARBs), and lifestyle modifications can slow the progression of diabetic nephropathy.
  • Patient Education: Understanding the stages of diabetic nephropathy enables patients to adhere to preventive strategies to delay or avoid progression to ESRD.

Tags:

  • Topic: Diabetic Nephropathy, Type 2 Diabetes
  • Difficulty: Must Know
  • PYQ: INICET MAY 2022

References: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, chap 404, pg NO: 3121-24

choices.text: Keloids do not extend beyond the original wound margin

questions.text: Which of the following is a distinguishing feature between keloids and hypertrophic scars?
questions.solution:
Keloid vs. Hypertrophic Scar:

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Keloids do not extend beyond the original wound margin: Incorrect. Keloids typically extend beyond the original wound margin, whereas hypertrophic scars do not.

Option B) Hypertrophic scars are more common on the earlobes: Incorrect. Keloids are more common on the earlobes, shoulders, and chest.

Option C) Keloids are less likely to regress over time: Correct. Keloids tend to persist and may even grow over time, whereas hypertrophic scars often regress over months.

Option D) Hypertrophic scars typically occur months after injury: Incorrect. Hypertrophic scars generally appear within weeks after the injury and remain within the wound margins.

Key Takeaways: Keloids vs. Hypertrophic Scars: Keloids extend beyond the original wound margin and are less likely to regress, while hypertrophic scars remain within the wound margin and usually improve over time.

questions.text: Identify the incision marked by yellow arrow in the following image:
questions.solution:
The Pfannenstiel incision is a transverse skin incision, two finger-breadths above the symphysis pubis, which is extended in the direction of the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and ends 2-3 cm medial to ASIS on both sides.

Usage: Frequently used for C-sections as it offers a strong closure and lower incidence of hernia formation.

Here's a brief definition for each of the incisions:

b. Joel-Cohen Incision

  • Definition: A straight transverse incision made slightly higher than the Pfannenstiel incision, about 3 cm above the pubic symphysis. It involves blunt dissection of the rectus muscles and less tissue trauma.
  • Usage: Known for faster healing and reduced blood loss, often preferred in elective cesarean deliveries.

c. Maylard Incision

  • Definition: A higher transverse incision, cutting through the rectus abdominis muscles, often located above the usual Pfannenstiel incision. It requires cutting the inferior epigastric vessels.
  • Usage: Used when greater access to the pelvis is required, such as in gynecological cancer surgeries.

d. Kerr's Incision

  • Definition: A low transverse uterine incision, commonly used during cesarean sections. It involves a horizontal cut on the lower uterine segment.
  • Usage: This incision reduces the risk of uterine rupture in future pregnancies, making it the most preferred method for cesarean sections.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Type: Must know

Topic: Abdominal incisions in gynaecology

PYQ: NEET

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Chapter 30, Caesarean delivery & Peripartum hysterectomy, Page no. 1417-1418

questions.text: Training is given to an ANM worker. Now you have to check her ability to do immunization. You are the medical officer. She is having a cotton, lunch box and syringe-needle after immunization of a child. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
• This question focuses on biomedical waste management and proper disposal practices following immunization.
  • Cotton swab disposal: After immunization, the cotton swab used for cleaning the injection site or to stop bleeding is classified as non-sharp infectious waste.
  • According to biomedical waste segregation guidelines, the cotton swab should be disposed of in a Yellow bag, designated for infectious non-sharp waste such as cotton, dressings, and swabs.

Waste Management Overview:

  • Syringe with needle:
    • Considered sharps waste and should be disposed of in a puncture-proof container (typically a translucent white container).
    • Important for preventing needle-stick injuries but not relevant to this question as it focuses on the cotton swab.
  • Used vial:
    • Immunization vials are usually discarded in the same container as sharps or separately, depending on local protocols.
    • Not applicable here as the question focuses on the cotton swab.
  • Food waste:
    • Should be disposed of in a Blue box, designated for general waste.
    • This option is irrelevant as it does not pertain to immunization waste management.

Why Not Others:

  • A: Syringe with needle in translucent White container: While this is true, the question specifically asks about the disposal method for the cotton swab.
  • B: Used Vial in translucent White container: This is a proper disposal method for vials, but it does not pertain to the cotton swab.
  • D: Food waste in Blue box: This is correct for food waste but is unrelated to the immunization context.

Key Takeaways:

  • Proper waste segregation is critical in healthcare to prevent infections and environmental hazards.
  • The Yellow bag is specifically designated for non-sharp infectious waste, highlighting the importance of following biomedical waste management protocols.

questions.text: All of the following are morphological features of Papillary thyroid carcinoma except:
questions.solution:
Nuclei shows fine dispersed chromatin and not smudged chromatin. Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that exhibits distinct microscopic features, including:

  1. Papillae: Finger-like projections of tumor cells supported by a fibrovascular core.
  2. Ground-glass nuclei: Enlarged, pale, and clear nuclei, finely dispersed chromatin with a characteristic "Orphan Annie eye" appearance.
  3. Nuclear grooves and pseudo inclusions: Deep grooves and pseudoinclusions (invaginations) in the nuclear membrane.
  4. Psammoma bodies: Small, round, laminated calcifications (often seen in the papillae).
  5. Multinucleation: Presence of multiple nuclei within a single cell.
  6. Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions: Cytoplasmic material within the nucleus.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 1088.

questions.text: The following diet is a not a risk factor for hypertension
questions.solution:
• High in potassium(D) is not a risk factor for hypertension. Potassium helps lower blood pressure by promoting sodium excretion and balancing the fluid levels in the body. It also helps relax the blood vessels, thereby reducing the pressure on the arterial walls. Good sources include bananas, oranges, spinach, potatoes, and beans.
  • Rich in sodium salts(A) is a major risk factor for hypertension. High sodium levels cause fluid retention, increasing blood volume and the force exerted on blood vessels, leading to higher blood pressure. Common sources of excessive sodium include processed foods, salty snacks, and canned goods.
  • Rich in saturated fats(B) can lead to the buildup of plaque in the arteries, narrowing blood vessels and raising blood pressure. Saturated fats also contribute to obesity and high cholesterol levels, both of which exacerbate hypertension. These fats are found in red meat, full-fat dairy products, and processed foods.
  • Rich in glucose(C), particularly refined sugars, can lead to weight gain, insulin resistance, and increased inflammation, all of which are linked to higher blood pressure. High glucose intake contributes to visceral fat accumulation, which negatively impacts blood pressure regulation.

Why Not Others:

  • Rich in sodium salts: Sodium is a well-established cause of hypertension, increasing fluid retention, which raises blood pressure.
  • Rich in saturated fats: Saturated fats contribute to vascular stiffness, which increases resistance in blood vessels and raises blood pressure over time.
  • Rich in glucose: High glucose intake, especially from sugary foods, can increase insulin levels, leading to insulin resistance and higher blood pressure. Excess body fat from sugar consumption also contributes to hypertension.

Key Takeaways:

  • A high potassium diet is essential for blood pressure control, counteracting sodium's effects and supporting vascular health.
  • Diets high in sodium, saturated fats, and glucose contribute to high blood pressure, cardiovascular disease, and obesity, all of which worsen hypertension.
  • Emphasizing foods like fruits, vegetables, and whole grains while limiting processed foods is key for preventing and managing hypertension.

Tags: inicet nov 2022

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K.park, 27th Edition, Chapter-6, Page no: 426-430.

questions.text: An elderly female patient presents with symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction, including persistent vomiting and upper abdominal pain. An endoscopic image reveals a large gallstone obstructing the duodenum. What clinical sign does this scenario describe?
questions.solution:
Bouveret's Syndrome

  • Bouveret's syndrome is a rare form of gallstone ileus where a large gallstone causes gastric outlet obstruction by lodging in the duodenum.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms include nausea, vomiting (often nonbilious), epigastric pain, and signs of dehydration.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Imaging: Xrays may show air in the biliary tree (pneumobilia), a large radiopaque gallstone, and signs of gastric dilatation.
    • Endoscopy: Confirms the presence of a gallstone obstructing the pylorus or duodenum.
    • CT Scan: Provides detailed visualisation of the stone, fistula, and level of obstruction.
  • Management:
    • Endoscopic Removal: Attempted initially to extract the stone if feasible.
    • Surgical Intervention: Required if endoscopic management fails, typically involving removal of the stone and repair of the fistula.

Complications:

  • Perforation of the duodenum, persistent obstruction, and recurrent gallstone formation.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Courvoisier's sign: Incorrect. Courvoisier's sign refers to a palpable, nontender gallbladder in patients with jaundice, often due to malignancy.

Option B. Mirizzi's syndrome: Incorrect. Mirizzi's syndrome involves obstruction of the common hepatic duct due to a gallstone impacted in the cystic duct.

Option C. Bouveret's syndrome: Correct. This syndrome is characterized by gastric outlet obstruction caused by a large gallstone passing into the duodenum

Option D. Gallstone ileus: Incorrect. Gallstone ileus typically causes obstruction in the ileum rather than at the level of the duodenum or stomach.

Key Points: Bouveret's syndrome involves gastric outlet obstruction due to a gallstone lodged in the duodenum.

Tags:

  • Topic: Bouveret's Syndrome
  • Difficulty Level: Good to Know
  • PYQ: NEET PG 2021

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 71, Page no: 1248

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, and her pelvic ultrasound reveals a cystic ovarian mass. An MRI of the pelvis is performed, showing a characteristic "dot-dash" pattern within the cyst. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Dermoid cysts, or mature cystic teratomas, often show a characteristic "dot-dash" pattern on MRI, where the "dots" represent areas of high signal intensity (often fat) and the "dashes" represent areas of lower signal intensity (often calcifications).

OPTION A: Endometrioma typically appears as a cyst with low signal intensity on T2-weighted MRI and may show internal echogenicity due to blood or endometrial tissue, but it does not exhibit the "dot-dash" pattern.

OPTION C: Ovarian cystadenoma typically appears as a unilocular or multilocular cystic mass on MRI without the characteristic "dot-dash" pattern.

OPTION D: Corpus luteal cysts usually appear as cystic masses with a more homogeneous appearance on MRI. They can show peripheral enhancement and do not typically display the "dot-dash" pattern. They are often associated with the menstrual cycle and may resolve spontaneously.

KEY TAKEAWAY: The "dot-dash" pattern observed on MRI is indicative of a dermoid cyst distinguishing it from other types of ovarian masses.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Ovarian mass

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Page no: 220.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a rash on the palms and soles of his feet as well as fever and headache. He was camping last weekend and admits to being bitten by a tick. His Weil-Felix test result is positive, suggesting Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Which of the following is the most suitable antibiotic that should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline, a tetracycline (30S ribosome inhibitor), is the antibiotic of choice to treat Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a rickettsial disease.

Option A, B & C: All of these given agents are not the preferred drug for Rocky Mountain spotted fever.

Key Takeaway:

  • Doxycycline is the antibiotic of choice to treat Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a rickettsial disease.

questions.text: A 43 year old male patient named Raman with history of epilepsy was on long term anticonvulsant therapy. After several years of treatment with anti-epileptic agent he presented to ophthalmology department with complaints of decrease visual field and visual disturbances. On fundus examination he was diagnosed of having retinal atrophy (as shown in the image below). Which of the following anti-epileptic drug is likely responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• Vigabatrin can result in irreversible visual field defects due to retinal atrophy.
  • Vigabatrin is an irreversible inhibitor of GABA transaminase, thus increases GABAergic activity.
  • It is the DOC for infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis (ACTH is DOC for all other cases).
  • It can result in irreversible visual field defects due to retinal atrophy.

Mnemonic:

Vigabatrin – Visual field defects

Option B: Ethosuximide causes gastrointestinal intolerance, tiredness, mood changes.

Option C: Phenobarbital Long term administration (as needed in epilepsy) may produce additional side effects like-behavioural abnormalities, diminution of intelligence, impairment of learning and memory, hyperactivity in children.

Option D: Levetiracetam can cause CNS adverse effects like irritability, aggression and lability of mood.

Key Takeaway:

  • Vigabatrin can result in irreversible visual field defects due to retinal atrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following sequence of deep cerebellar nuclei is correct arrangement from medial to lateral side?
questions.solution:
Deep Cerebellar Nuclei

  • Medullary Core: Contains the four deep cerebellar nuclei, crucial for cerebellar function.
  • Nuclei Description:
    • Fastigial Nucleus: Medial and adjacent to the fourth ventricle, involved in balance and posture.
    • Globose Nucleus: Located laterally to the fastigial nucleus; part of the caudomedial group.
    • Emboliform Nucleus: Medial to the dentate nucleus; part of the rostrolateral group.
    • Dentate Nucleus: Lateralmost and largest, responsible for planning and timing of movements.
  • Interconnected Groups:
    • Caudomedial Group: Comprises the fastigial and globose nuclei.
    • Rostrolateral Group: Consists of the emboliform and dentate nuclei.

Key takeaways: mnemonic : lateral to medial cerebellar nuclei

DEGF: Dentate nuclei, Emboliform nuclei, Globose nuclei, Fastigial nuclei

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department, as he was severely dehydrated. Dehydration is most commonly seen in children. Which of the following statement justify it?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ratio of ECF volume to ICF volume is larger in infants and children than in adults. However, as the total volume of ECF is much smaller in children than in adults. In addition, the regulatory mechanisms for maintaining ECF volume are not well developed in infants and children. Therefore, dehydration is more common and occurs rapidly in children than in adults.

Option A: Incorrect because the ratio of ECF to ICF volume is actually larger in children, not adults.

Option B: Incorrect because the ratio of ICF volume to ECF volume is smaller in children than in adults.

Option D: Incorrect because the ratio of ECF volume to ICF volume is larger in children, not smaller.

Key takeaways: The ratio of ECF volume to ICF volume is larger in children than in adults, making dehydration more common in children due to smaller total ECF volume and underdeveloped regulatory mechanisms.

Reference: Textbook of Medical Physiology Guyton 14th Edition Page no. 315

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to her family physician complaining of fatigue. On investigation Hematocrit: 30%, red blood cell smear: Microcytic hypochromic cells, serum iron values: 27 μg/dL, transferrin saturation: 13%, Serum ferritin: 20 μg/L. Probable diagnosis is iron deficiency anaemia is prescribed oral iron supplements. Which of the following food should she avoid taking along with these supplements?
questions.solution:
Option B: Oxalate inhibits the iron absorption by binding and forming insoluble complexes which prevents its GI absorption.

Factors affecting iron absorption:

Why Not Others:

Option A: Citric Acid: Enhances iron absorption and is beneficial when taking iron supplements.

Option C: Ascorbic Acid: Also enhances iron absorption, making it a good choice to take with supplements.

Option D: Amino Acid: Generally enhances iron absorption and does not inhibit it.

Key takeaways: In iron deficiency anemia, the patient should avoid foods containing oxalates while taking oral iron supplements, as they inhibit iron absorption.

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient with a recent history of acute Myocardial infarction was prescribed an antiplatelet agent acting via P2Y12 inhibition. Later that patient came to medicine department with complaints of Dyspnea. Which of the following agents is commonly associated Dyspnea?
questions.solution:
Ticagrelor is more commonly associated with dyspnea.

The dyspnea is transient and not associated with pulmonary disease. Other Side effects are dizziness, nausea, shortness of breath, tightness in chest and irregular pulse.

Dyspnea is more commonly seen with reversible P2Y12 inhibitors like ticagrelor, cangrelor and elinogrel. It is uncommon with irreversible P2Y12 inhibitors like clopidogrel, prasugrel and ticlopidine.

Option A, B & D: Dyspnea is uncommon with irreversible P2Y12 inhibitors like clopidogrel, prasugrel and ticlopidine.

Key Takeaway:

  • Ticagrelor is more commonly associated with dyspnea amongst P2Y12 inhibitors. Dyspnea is more seen with reversible P2Y12 inhibitors.

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.text: A 40 year old male presents to the emergency department after a high speed motor vehicle accident. He is hypotensive and tachycardic, with severe pain in the pelvis. A physical examination reveals pelvic instability. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Option B: External pelvic binder application is Correct. The application of a pelvic binder is essential to stabilise the pelvis and reduce haemorrhage, especially in unstable pelvic fractures.

Pelvic Trauma:

Pelvic fractures are often associated with significant trauma and can lead to severe complications, including haemorrhage, organ injury, and neurological damage.

Classification: Tile Classification System

The Tile Classification System provides a framework for categorising pelvic fractures based on the degree of pelvic ring disruption:

  • Type A (Stable Fractures): No disruption of the pelvic ring, typically involving avulsion fractures or isolated iliac wing fractures.
  • Type B (Partially Stable Fractures): Involves rotational instability but intact vertical stability. Openbook fractures are a common example.
  • Type C (Unstable Fractures): Both rotational and vertical instability, often associated with vertical shear injuries or complex pelvic fractures.

Initial Assessment and Management

  • Primary Survey (ABCDE): Prioritise airway, breathing, circulation, disability, and exposure to identify and address immediate life-threatening conditions.
  • Pelvic Stability: Gently assess pelvic stability to avoid exacerbating the injury.
  • Haemorrhage Control:
    • Pelvic Binder: A first-line intervention to stabilise the pelvis and reduce bleeding.
    • Angiography with Embolization: Consider for ongoing bleeding despite pelvic binder application, particularly in hemodynamically stable patients.
    • Surgical Intervention: Necessary in hemodynamically unstable patients with uncontrolled haemorrhage.

Imaging and Definitive Care

  • Pelvic X-ray: Initial imaging to assess fracture pattern and displacement.
  • CT Scan: Provides detailed imaging of bony structures and associated injuries, including vascular and visceral damage.
  • Definitive Care:
    • Surgical Repair: Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) is often required for unstable pelvic fractures to restore structural integrity and stability.

Complications :

  • Hemorrhagic Shock: The rich vascular supply in the pelvis can lead to significant blood loss.
  • Urogenital Injury: Common in pelvic fractures, requiring careful assessment and management, including retrograde urethrogram.
  • Neurological Injury: Potential injury to the lumbosacral plexus, leading to sensory and motor deficits.

Option A: Immediate pelvic X Ray: Important for diagnosis, but stabilising the pelvis to control haemorrhage is more critical as the first step.

Option B: External pelvic binder application is Correct. The application of a pelvic binder is essential to stabilise the pelvis and reduce haemorrhage, especially in unstable pelvic fractures.

Option C : CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is Necessary for detailed assessment, but only after initial stabilisation.

Option D: Exploratory laparotomy is Indicated if there is intra abdominal haemorrhage or hollow organ injury, but not the first step in isolated pelvic trauma.

Key Takeaway:

Tags:

  • Topic: Pelvic Trauma – Assessment and Management
  • Difficulty Level: Good to Know
  • PYQ: Inicet May 2023

References: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 62, Pages 1300-1302.

questions.text: A 24 year old primigravida reports to LR at 37 weeks of gestation in early labour. USG shows a single live intrauterine fetus of 36 weeks 5 days gestation FHR 150 bpm, AFI 3 cm, EFW 2.6 kg. Identify the pattern of CTG shown below:
questions.solution:
• The image shows variable decelerations.
  • Variable decelerations are variable in onset, duration and depth.
  • They may occur with contractions or between contractions.
  • Typically, they have an abrupt onset and rapid recovery.
  • Oligohydramnios is associated with more frequent variable decelerations as the amniotic fluid has a protective role on the fetal umbilical cord, and studies have suggested that the use of amnioinfusion may improve the FHR pattern.

Optionwise explanation:

Option a) Early Deceleration

  • The FHR decline mirrors the contraction in timing, creating a "mirror image" where the nadir (lowest point) of the FHR occurs at the peak of the contraction.
  • Early decelerations are usually benign and do not indicate fetal distress. They are common in late labor as the fetal head descends into the pelvis.

Option b) Late Deceleration

  • Definition: Late decelerations are gradual decreases in FHR that begin after the peak of a uterine contraction and return to baseline after the contraction ends.
  • Cause: They are caused by uteroplacental insufficiency, which results in decreased oxygenation to the fetus.
  • Pattern: The deceleration starts after the contraction has begun, and the lowest point of FHR occurs after the peak of the contraction.
  • Clinical Significance: Late decelerations can be a sign of fetal hypoxia and distress, especially when repetitive and associated with minimal variability or bradycardia. They may require intervention, such as changing maternal position, oxygen administration, or even urgent delivery.

Option d) Sinusoidal Pattern

  • Definition: A sinusoidal pattern is a smooth, wave-like oscillation of the FHR with regular amplitude and frequency, without normal short-term variability.
  • Cause: It is associated with severe fetal anemia, fetal hypoxia, or other serious fetal conditions (e.g., Rh isoimmunization, fetal-maternal hemorrhage).
  • Pattern: The pattern has a fixed, undulating waveform that lasts for at least 20 minutes.
  • Clinical Significance: A true sinusoidal pattern is considered an ominous sign of severe fetal distress or anemia and requires immediate evaluation and usually prompt delivery.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Variable Deceleration

  • Definition: Variable decelerations are abrupt decreases in FHR that vary in timing, duration, and shape, often resembling "V", "U", or "W" patterns.
  • Cause: They are usually caused by umbilical cord compression, which leads to a brief reduction in blood flow to the fetus.
  • Pattern: The onset and recovery of variable decelerations are quick and may or may not be associated with contractions.
  • Clinical Significance: Occasional variable decelerations are common and may not be concerning if the variability remains normal. However, recurrent or severe variable decelerations, especially with slow recovery or reduced variability, may indicate fetal compromise and require intervention.

Type: Must know

Topic: Variable deceleration

Reference: Munro Kerr’s Operative Obstetrics 12th edition, Chapter 6, Fetal Surveillance in Labour, Page no. 43

questions.text: Koebner's phenomenon is seen in all except
questions.solution:
Koebner phenomenon is a dermatological condition characterized by the appearance of new skin lesions at sites of injury, such as cuts, scrapes, or burns. These lesions often resemble the original skin condition.

Key characteristics of Koebner phenomenon:

  • New lesions appear at sites of injury: This is the defining feature of Koebner phenomenon.
  • Lesions resemble the original skin condition: The new lesions often have the same appearance, texture, and characteristics as the existing skin condition.
  • Can occur with various skin conditions: Koebner phenomenon can be associated with a wide range of skin disorders, including psoriasis, lichen planus, vitiligo, and atopic dermatitis.

Option D: Herpes Infection Doesn’t show kobener phenomenon.

Key Takeaway :

The Koebner phenomenon is a dermatological condition characterized by the appearance of new skin lesions at sites of injury seen in psoriasis, lichen planus and vitiligo.

Tag:

  • Signs in dermatology
  • Must know
  • NEET PG 2020 | FMGE Dec 2020 | FMGE June 2022

Reference: Rook’s textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, page no 123.2

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male, who works in a battery manufacturing plant, presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of progressive slowness of movement, muscle stiffness, and postural instability over the past six months. He denies any tremor. He has a history of working with manganese compounds without adequate protective equipment for several years. On examination, he exhibits rigidity and bradykinesia but no rest tremor.
Which of the following is the most likely site of damage in this patient's brain?
questions.solution:
1. Manganese toxicity is known to predominantly affect the globus pallidus. This region is highly sensitive to manganese deposition, which can lead to neurological symptoms resembling atypical parkinsonism.
  2. Clinical Features of manganese toxicity include rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability, similar to Parkinsonian symptoms but without the characteristic resting tremor of Parkinson's disease.
  3. Why Other Options are Incorrect:
    • Substantia nigra: This area is typically affected in idiopathic Parkinson’s disease, where dopamine-producing neurons degenerate. Manganese toxicity specifically spares this region.
    • Subthalamic nucleus (STN): This structure is not primarily involved in manganese toxicity and is more relevant in surgical interventions like deep brain stimulation.
    • Cerebellum: This region is related to coordination and balance but is not the primary site of manganese toxicity, which affects basal ganglia structures instead.

Carbon monoxide and manganese toxicity are known to cause damage predominantly to the globus pallidus. This specific susceptibility is due to the high metabolic activity in this region, making it vulnerable to hypoxic and toxic injuries.

Presentation often resembles atypical parkinsonism, which includes rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability. However, unlike classic Parkinson's disease, tremors may be less prominent.

Incorrect Options:

  • Substantia nigra: This region is more commonly affected in Parkinson's disease due to degeneration of dopaminergic neurons but is not the primary site for damage in carbon monoxide or manganese toxicity.
  • Subthalamic nucleus (STN): Typically involved in motor control and may be surgically targeted in deep brain stimulation for Parkinson's disease but is not specifically damaged by carbon monoxide or manganese.
  • All of the above: Only the globus pallidus is the principal structure affected by these toxic exposures, making this option incorrect.

Key Takeaways:

  • Occupational exposure to manganese can lead to damage in the globus pallidus and cause symptoms resembling atypical parkinsonism.
  • A lack of resting tremor helps differentiate manganese toxicity from classic Parkinson's disease.
  • The globus pallidus is particularly vulnerable to toxic and metabolic damage, especially from heavy metals like manganese.

Tags:

  • Topic: Neurology, Secondary Parkinson
  • Difficulty: Must Know
  • PYQ: FMGE JUNE 2022; JUNE 2021

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, 435, pg 3386

questions.text: What is the earliest lesion in atherosclerosis?
questions.solution:
A fatty streak is an early sign of atherosclerosis.

  • A fatty streak is a flat, yellowish patch on the innermost layer of the artery wall, composed of:
  • Lipid-laden macrophages (foam cells)
  • T lymphocytes
  • Smooth muscle cells

Option B: An atherosclerotic plaque is a complex lesion that forms in the artery wall, leading to atherosclerosis.

  • Composition: Atherosclerotic plaques consist of
    • Lipid core (cholesterol, triglycerides)
    • Fibrous cap (smooth muscle cells, collagen)
    • Inflammatory cells (macrophages, T lymphocytes)
    • Calcification

Option C: Aneurysm formation: Atherosclerosis induced pressure or ischemic atrophy of underlying media, with loss of elastic tissue, causes weakness and potential rupture.

Option D: Ulceration of the surface of atheromatous plaques exposes the blood stream to highly thrombogenic substances and leads to thrombosis.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 499.

choices.text: Reduced thyroid hormone metabolism by placental deiodinase

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in her first trimester of pregnancy is found to have mildly decreased TSH levels on routine testing. Her total T4 is elevated, but her free T4 is within the normal range. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
• During pregnancy, estrogen leads to an increase in thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG), which raises the levels of total T4 and total T3. However, the free (unbound) hormone levels usually remain within the normal range, as seen in this patient.
  • The human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) produced in early pregnancy can weakly stimulate the TSH receptor, leading to a transient decrease in TSH.

OPTION B: There is no decreased iodine requirement during pregnancy; in fact, iodine requirements increase

OPTION C: Placental type III deiodinase increases thyroid hormone metabolism, rather than reducing it

OPTION D Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) are seen in Graves' disease, not in normal pregnancy

Key Takeaways:

  • Estrogen increases TBG during pregnancy, which elevates total T4 and T3 levels while keeping free hormone levels normal.
  • The rise in hCG during the first trimester can transiently suppress TSH levels.
  • Iodine requirements are increased during pregnancy due to increased renal excretion and fetal use.

Tags:

  • Topic: Thyroid Function in Pregnancy
  • Difficulty Level: Good to Know
  • PYQ Reference: NEET PG 2021, Endocrinology

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 382, Page no. 2929.

choices.text: Single or multiple trans dermal bites or licks on broken skin

questions.text: True about category III bite is:
questions.solution:
• Single or multiple transdermal bites or licks on broken skin: True. Category III represents the most severe exposure to rabies, which includes deep bites or licks on broken skin, allowing the virus to enter through a puncture wound. This requires immediate medical attention, including post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) with rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) and the rabies vaccination series.
  • Nibbling of uncovered skin: False. This refers to Category II exposure, which involves minor abrasions or scratches without significant bleeding. The risk is lower compared to Category III.
  • Minor scratches: False. This is also Category II exposure, which is considered a moderate risk for rabies transmission.
  • Licks on broken skin: False. This is considered Category II exposure, which poses a moderate risk, as the saliva of a rabid animal can contain the virus but may not always lead to infection.

Why Not Others:

  • B. Nibbling of uncovered skin: Incorrect. It corresponds to Category II, involving minimal risk.
  • C. Minor scratches: Incorrect. This is classified under Category II, which requires monitoring but is not as critical as Category III.
  • D. Licks on broken skin: Incorrect. This is a Category II exposure, which requires attention but does not demand immediate PEP.

Key Takeaways:

  • Category III involves the highest-risk exposures, such as deep bites or licks on broken skin, requiring immediate PEP.
  • Category II exposures include minor scratches, nibbling, and licks on unbroken skin, with a moderate risk for rabies transmission.

Tags: INICET may 2023

Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K.park,27th Edition,Chapter-5,Page no.322-327

questions.text: Most common cause of vesicovaginal fistula in India is:
questions.solution:
Obstructed labour is the most common cause of vesicovaginal fistula in India. Prolonged pressure of the fetal head against the bladder during obstructed labour can lead to ischemic necrosis and subsequent formation of a fistula between the bladder and the vagina. This is particularly prevalent in low-resource settings where access to timely obstetric care is limited.

Vesicovaginal fistula-

OPTION A: Wertheim’s hysterectomy

This is a radical hysterectomy often performed for cervical cancer, which can occasionally lead to vesicovaginal fistula as a complication. However, it is not the most common cause in India.

OPTION B: Cervical Cancer

Cervical cancer can cause a vesicovaginal fistula due to direct invasion of the tumor or radiation therapy used in its treatment. Although a possible cause, it is not the most prevalent reason in India.

OPTION C: Vesical Cancer

Cancer of the bladder can lead to the formation of fistulas with adjacent organs, including the vagina. However, this is a relatively rare cause compared to others.

Take away -In countries like India Mc cause of vvf is obstructed labour while in high resource setting countries iatrogenic causes (related to surgeries) are common

Type: Must know

Topic: Genitourinary fistula

PYQ: INICET,NEET

Reference: Shaw’s Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 379-380

Bismuth subsalicylate :

It is thought to act by decreasing PG synthesis in the intestinal mucosa, thereby reducing Cl¯ secretion.

It has some prophylactic value in travellers’ diarrhoea (probably due to weak antibacterial action as well)

Dark stools (sometimes mistaken for melena) and black staining of the tongue in association with bismuth compounds are caused by bismuth sulfide formed in a reaction between the drug and bacterial sulfides in the GI tract.

questions.text: A mother brings her newborn baby to a pediatric with complaints of constant crying and vomiting. The baby was diagnosed with genetically reduced number of chief cells in the stomach. What would be the problem the baby might be facing?
questions.solution:
Option D: Peptic cells or chief cells secrete pepsinogen, which is converted to pepsin in the acidic pH of stomach and digests proteins.

Intrinsic factor responsible for B12 absorption and HCl responsible for the acidity of stomach are secreted of oxyntic or parietal cells.

Mucus that prevents ulceration of the mucosa is secreted by mucus neck cells.

Other options:

Option A: Difficulty in absorbing B12: This is primarily due to lack of intrinsic factor, produced by parietal cells, not chief cells.

Option B: Less acidity of the stomach: Chief cells do not directly affect stomach acidity, which is mainly regulated by parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid.

Option C: Ulceration of the gut mucosa: While low pepsin may affect digestion, it does not directly cause ulceration, which is more related to excess acid or other factors.

Key takeaways: Chief cells secrete pepsinogen for protein digestion, while parietal cells produce intrinsic factor for B12 absorption and hydrochloric acid for acidity, with mucus neck cells preventing mucosal ulceration.

Tags: Good to know

Reference: Ganong’s review of medical physiology, 26th edition, Page 1050, 1051

choices.text: 1,25 Di OH Vitamin D level

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to orthopaedic department having clinical manifestations like softening of skull, costochondral junction swelling, and pigeon chest. A probable diagnosis of Rickets was made. Most specific test for diagnosis of Vitamin D deficiency is?
questions.solution:
Option D: Rickets: Commonly caused by Vitamin D deficiency, presenting with bone deformities in children.

  • Most Specific Test: 25 OH Vitamin D (Calcidiol) levels provide the most accurate measure of vitamin D status.
    • Reason: Calcidiol reflects overall vitamin D stores in the body.
    • 1,25-Dihydroxyvitamin D (Calcitriol): Often normal in severe vitamin D deficiency, hence not reliable for diagnosis.

Why Not Others:

Option A: 1,25 Di OH Vitamin D level: Can remain normal even in severe deficiency, making it less specific.

Option B: 1-alpha hydroxylase level: Reflects enzyme activity related to vitamin D metabolism but is not used for diagnosing deficiency.

Option C: Osteoprotegerin levels: Related to bone remodelling, not specific to vitamin D deficiency.

Key takeaways: Rickets is commonly caused by vitamin D deficiency, and the most specific test for diagnosis is measuring 25 OH Vitamin D levels.

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition Page no. 378

questions.text: A 51-year-old male presents with shortness of breath after climbing stairs. Patient has chronic cough. His respiratory rate is 30 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Pulmonary function tests show decreased forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and reduced FEV1/FVC ratio. What is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
• COPD is a chronic, progressive lung disease commonly caused by smoking, characterized by persistent airflow limitation. COPD is characterized by airway obstruction, resulting in decreased FEV1 and a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio. It often presents with chronic shortness of breath and may be linked to a history of smoking.
  • Asthma is a chronic inflammatory condition of the airways characterized by intermittent airflow obstruction. Asthma: While asthma also causes decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio, it is usually reversible and often linked to wheezing and specific triggers.
  • Pulmonary fibrosis is a form of restrictive lung disease that leads to scarring and stiffening of the lung tissue. Pulmonary fibrosis: Causes restrictive lung disease and typically shows a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio.
  • A pulmonary embolism (PE) is a blockage of one of the pulmonary arteries due to a blood clot. Pulmonary embolism: Causes sudden onset shortness of breath with normal pulmonary function tests.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A. Asthma: Often reversible and presents with wheezing, unlike COPD.
  • B. Pulmonary fibrosis: Results in a restrictive pattern, not an obstructive pattern as seen in COPD.
  • D. Pulmonary embolism: Sudden onset, with normal PFT results, unlike COPD's chronic progression.

Key Takeaways:

  • COPD is characterized by decreased FEV1 and reduced FEV1/FVC ratio due to airway obstruction.
  • Asthma is reversible, and pulmonary fibrosis and embolism present differently.

Tags: NEET 2022

Reference: Guyton and Hall, 14th edition, Chapter 42, p. 517

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of migraines develops unilateral headache with tearing and redness of the eye, occurring multiple times a day during a cluster period. Which of the following is an appropriate preventive treatment?
questions.solution:
• Option B (Verapamil) is Correct: Verapamil is the first-line preventive treatment for cluster headaches, which are characterized by severe, unilateral pain often associated with autonomic symptoms such as tearing, redness of the eye, nasal congestion, and ptosis. Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that has been shown to be effective in reducing the frequency and severity of cluster headache attacks when used prophylactically.
  • Option A (Triptans) is Incorrect: While triptans (e.g., sumatriptan) are effective in acute treatment of cluster headaches, they are not used as preventive therapy. Triptans are typically administered during an attack to relieve pain but do not prevent future attacks.
  • Option C (Opioids) is Incorrect: Opioids are not recommended for treating or preventing cluster headaches due to their risk of dependence and side effects. Cluster headaches respond better to specific therapies like verapamil for prevention and oxygen or triptans for acute relief.
  • Option D (Indomethacin) is Incorrect: Indomethacin is effective in treating paroxysmal hemicrania, another type of headache disorder, but it is not effective in preventing cluster headaches. Indomethacin is not used for cluster headache management.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Cluster headaches are characterized by unilateral head pain with autonomic symptoms like tearing and redness of the eye.
  2. Verapamil is the first-line preventive treatment for cluster headaches, helping to reduce the frequency of attacks.
  3. Triptans are used for acute treatment, while opioids and indomethacin are generally not appropriate for managing cluster headaches.

Tags:

  • Topic: Neurology, Cluster Headache Management
  • Difficulty Level: Good to Know
  • PYQ: INICET NOV 2021

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 430, Page no. 3357-69.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of Asherman syndrome?
questions.solution:
Asherman syndrome is characterized by the formation of intrauterine adhesions (scar tissue) that can lead to menstrual disturbances and infertility.

  • The most common cause of Asherman syndrome is postpartum or post-abortion curettage.
  • The procedure can lead to trauma to the uterine lining (endometrium), resulting in scarring and adhesions, particularly if the curettage is performed aggressively or if there is infection.

Optionwise explanation:

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID): While PID can lead to tubal damage and infertility, it is not a common cause of Asherman syndrome. PID typically affects the fallopian tubes and pelvic organs rather than causing intrauterine adhesions.
  • Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. Although it can lead to infertility and pelvic pain, it does not typically cause the intrauterine adhesions seen in Asherman syndrome.
  • Schistosomiasis: Schistosomiasis, a parasitic infection, can lead to pelvic fibrosis and infertility, but it is a much less common cause of Asherman syndrome compared to curettage.

Key takeaway:

The most common cause of Asherman syndrome is postpartum or post-abortion curettage, which can lead to intrauterine scarring and adhesions.

Reference: Speroff’s Clinical Gynaecologic Endocrinology & Infertility 9th edition, Chapter 10 Amenorrhoea, Page no. 864-865

questions.text: A 34 year old male presented with skin lesion over lower back, scalp. On eliciting a clinical test, there was pinpoint bleeding. This sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
When scales of psoriasis are scraped, characteristic coherence of a silvery scale like a candle wax is seen (Grattage test).

The Auspitz sign is a clinical feature observed in certain skin conditions. It refers to the appearance of small bleeding points when the top layer of a lesion is gently scraped off. This sign is most commonly seen in psoriasis vulgaris, but it can also be present in other conditions such as Darier disease and actinic keratosis.

Conditions where Auspitz sign is not typically seen:

  • Inverse psoriasis: This type of psoriasis affects skin folds and is not usually associated with the Auspitz sign.
  • Pustular psoriasis: This condition involves the formation of pus-filled blisters and does not typically exhibit the Auspitz sign.
  • Guttate psoriasis: This type of psoriasis is characterized by small, drop-like lesions and does not usually show the Auspitz sign.
  • Erythrodermic psoriasis: This severe form of psoriasis involves widespread redness and scaling of the skin and is not typically associated with the Auspitz sign.

Auspitz sign seen in- Psoriasis vulgaris, Darier disease, Actinic keratosis

Not seen in - Inverse psoriasis, pustular psoriasis, guttate psoriasis, erythrodermic psoriasis (Option C)

Option A- Nikolsky sign is seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

Option C - Auspitz sign seen in- Psoriasis vulgaris, Darier disease, Actinic keratosis. Not seen in - Inverse psoriasis, pustular psoriasis, guttate psoriasis, erythrodermic psoriasis

Option D- Tin tack sign is seen in DLE (Discoid lupus erythematosus).

Key takeaway:

When scales are completely scraped off, basement membrane is exposed as seen as moist red surface( membrane of Bulkeley) through which dilated capillaries at the top of elongated dermal papillae are torn, leading to multiple bleeding points.This sign is known as Auspitz sign.

Tag:

  • Bedside tests in dermatology
  • Auspitz sign
  • Must know
  • FMGE Aug 2020

Reference: Rook’s textbook of dermatology, 9th edition.Pg no 35.9

questions.text: What is the primary toxin responsible for the clinical manifestations of tetanus?
questions.solution:
• A. Tetanolysin:
    • While produced by C. tetani, it is not involved in the pathology of tetanus.
    • Primarily associated with hemolytic activity but does not contribute to muscle spasms.
  • B. Tetanospasmin:
    • This neurotoxin is responsible for the characteristic muscle spasms and other clinical manifestations of tetanus.
    • It interferes with neurotransmitter release, leading to uncontrollable contractions.
  • C. Enterotoxin:
    • C. tetani does not produce an enterotoxin, which is typically associated with gastrointestinal pathogens.
  • D. Neurotoxin A:
    • This term does not refer to any toxin produced by C. tetani and is not recognized in the context of tetanus.

Why Not Others:

  • A: Tetanolysin is involved in hemolysis but does not cause tetanus symptoms.
  • C: Enterotoxins are linked to gastrointestinal diseases, not tetanus.
  • D: Neurotoxin A is not a recognized entity associated with C. tetani.

Key Takeaway: Tetanospasmin is the primary neurotoxin responsible for the clinical symptoms of tetanus, leading to severe muscle spasms and rigidity, critical for understanding tetanus pathology and treatment.

Tags:

  • NEET 2020
  • Easy

Reference: Shastri, A. (2021). Essentials of Medical Microbiology (3rd ed.). Publisher. Chapter-72 Tetanus. pp-702-704.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. An endoscopic biopsy of the small intestine

Which of the following conditions is most likely based on these findings?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Whipple's Disease – Correct. Whipple's Disease is characterized by the presence of macrophages in the lamina propria that are PAS-positive, which helps distinguish it from other causes of chronic diarrhea and malabsorption. This feature is specific to Whipple’s Disease and results from Tropheryma whipplei infection.
  • Option B: Celiac Disease – Incorrect. Celiac Disease typically shows villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and mononuclear cell infiltration. It does not exhibit PAS-positive macrophages.
  • Option C: Crohn’s Disease – Incorrect. Crohn’s Disease pathology often includes noncaseating granulomas in the lamina propria and submucosa but does not have PAS-positive macrophages as seen in Whipple's Disease.
  • Option D: Intestinal Lymphangiectasia – Incorrect. Intestinal Lymphangiectasia is characterized by dilated lymphatics and clubbed villi on biopsy, not PAS-positive macrophages.

Key Takeaways:

  • Whipple’s Disease is identified by PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria, which is a hallmark finding.
  • Celiac Disease and Tropical Sprue both show villous atrophy but lack the PAS-positive macrophages seen in Whipple’s Disease.
  • Crohn’s Disease has noncaseating granulomas as a distinguishing histologic feature.
  • Intestinal Lymphangiectasia presents with dilated lymphatics and clubbed villi rather than macrophage infiltration.

Tags:

  • Topic: Gastrointestinal Pathology, Whipple's Disease
  • Difficulty: Must Know
  • PYQ: INICET MAY 2022; FMGE DEC 2021

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter 325, pg 2458-68

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a long history of severe type 2 diabetes had been taking multiple daily injections of insulin, including an insulin glargine preparation. Which of the following sets of properties (Given in the table below) best describes the time course of effects of this preparation?
questions.solution:
• Insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin analogue that was designed to provide a broad plasma concentration plateau.
  • It has an onset of action of 1 to 4 hours, achieves a maximum effect after 4 to 6 hours, and can maintain this effect for over 24 hours.
  • It is usually given once daily to provide basal levels of insulin

Option A: SemiLente insulin Shows this type of pharmacokinetic.

Option B & C: These pharmacokinetic data matches with short acting insulin like lispro, aspart and glulisine.

Key Takeaway

  • Insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin analogue, it has an onset of action of 1 to 4 hours, achieves a maximum effect after 4 to 6 hours, and can maintain this effect for over 24 hours.
